Included in this contribution, it is proposed to support NRC's capacity to address new emerging humanitarian needs in rapid onset crises. Sida's funding Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) allocation to NRC will enable NRC to react very fast to new disasters when they strike. It may provide seed funding to larger response programmes and catalyze more resources, complementing as well the resources that the flexibility of PBA provides for re-allocating them in such circumstances, when possible. In 2020, NRC tapped into its 50 MSEK allocation 15 times, replenished once, until it was exhausted, intervening in 13 countries where NRC had presence in the context of sudden displacement situations, floods, droughts and socio-economic consequences of COVID-19 on displaced and vulnerable households. The assistance provided consisted generally in protection services and assistance delivered in form of cash, vouchers, and in-kind life-saving commodities, in the areas of shelter, basic assistance kits, hygiene promotion and psychosocial support. In 2021, NRC will undertake similar interventions with the RRM allocation with an initial 40 MSEK funding from Sida. RRM interventions are considered as projects, implemented over a 3 to 6 month period, with a 3 MSEK budget in average. The ceiling is 5 MSEK, while the bottom budget is 2 MSEK, but exceptions can be justified case by case.
Method- and capacity-building projects
Included in this contribution, NRC has proposed to Sida to support Method- and capacity-building projects that will contribute to improve the global humanitarian system and coordination & advocacy forums at the national level.
- Strengthening global protection policy for displacement communities is a project that Sida is willing to prioritize as it focuses on ensuring effective integration of protection across NRC programming and improvements to global humanitarian protection policy by translating concepts into concrete actionable outcomes. This project aims at ensuring that protection is foundational to all NRC work through the ‘Safe Programming’ framework defining minimum commitments for NRC's operations, and at supporting the full realisation of the right of freedom of movement in safety and dignity for displacement-affected persons, in programmes for the protection of civilians, for durable solutions and for migrants in 'refugee-like' situations.
- Becoming the leading displacement organization in hard to reach areas (H2R) is a project that will be supported in 2021 by Sida. It addresses the growing complexity of operating environments by investing in in-depth understanding of contexts against the backdrop of shifting international norms and the rise of new tech solutions to ensure timely and appropriate responses. NRC wants to ensure that displacement-affected individuals considered hard-to-reach have better access to assistance and protection, by enhancing NRC's ability to access multiple geographical and cultural H2R contexts, by delivering high quality and sustained programming in H2R areas and by advocating for the rights of people affected by displacement in H2R areas.
- Sida's support to NRC's CashCap will be continued in 2021. The project ensures that humanitarian/development agencies and national actors have sufficient and sustained expertise to design and implement cash and market-based response (CMBR) in an effective and coordinated manner. NRC intends to ensure global rapid deployment capacity for the initial days of a sudden onset emergency and to enable the systematic consideration of cash and voucher assistance as part of the initial response analysis. NRC will facilitate knowledge exchange, provide technical backstop and support to CashCap roster members on deployment, and improve sustainability between CashCap expert and cash community by sharing information, promoting continuity and encouraging to take ownership by the cash community.
- NRC’s Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC) in Geneva will continue to be co-financed by Sida's humanitarian unit and Sida's unit for Global Cooperation on Environment in 2021. IDMC is a global leader in monitoring, reporting on and advocating for people displaced within their own country. It is known for its research publications and advocacy aiming at generating evidence on all situations of internal displacement; building capacity to prevent and respond to the issue; and galvanising political commitment and action to drive positive change. For the second and probably last year, Sida's Unit for Global Cooperation on Environment will co-finance IDMC in 2021 together with the Humanitarian Unit, as IDMC analyzes displacement situation trends caused by climate change as well. IDMC adds great value to the evidence- and needs-based mobilization of resources for displacement situations. Its analysis and research are major contributions to the global and local advocacy agenda.
- NRC will be supported as well through this contribution for hosting local humanitarian coordination platforms where international and local NGOs cooperate for building up coordinated programmes, common advocacy agendas and for influencing the policy-making of authorities, the UN, donors and other partners. These forums play a key role in localizing the response, offering coordination services, training and partnership opportunities to the local NGO community. They play as well an important role for INGOs in addressing administrative and access obstacles that they may face with authorities for establishing themselves and obtaining visas and work permits. The Jordan INGO Forum and the Libya INGO Forum will be supported through this contribution. NRC's active engagement in the local NGO forums, sometimes by hosting them with Sida's support (DRC, Palestine (AIDA), Jordan, Libya, Lebanon until (2019)), demonstrates NRC's commitment to aid effectiveness and collective action regarding humanitarian coordination and advocacy.
- Furthermore, it is proposed to continue co-financing for a last year the West Bank Protection Consortium (WBPC) with the Swedish General Consulate in Jerusalem and other donors. It is a strategic partnership between DG ECHO, 10 European States and 5 INGOs providing protection and assistance to Palestinians at risk of forcible transfer in the West Bank due to recurrent violations of international law. The project addresses the protection needs of persons and communities of concern through a multi-sector approach that reduces vulnerabilities, builds capacities and responds to threats. The Consulate has established a 3 year partnership 2021-2023 with NRC (#14571, 39 MSEK) for that project. The WBPC project, and the NGO platform AIDA, supported so far by Sida's humanitarian unit, will be funded by Sweden's development cooperation strategy for Palestine, integrated in that contribution.

title: FAO HUM 2021-2025
description:
FAO’s Global Goals are:
1. Eradication of hunger, food insecurity and malnutrition, progressively ensuring a world in which people at all times have sufficient safe and nutritious food that meets their dietary needs and food preferences for an active and healthy life;
2. Elimination of poverty and the driving forward of economic and social progress for all, with increased food production, enhanced rural development and sustainable livelihoods;
3. Sustainable management and utilization of natural resources, including land, water, air, climate and genetic resources for the benefit of present and future generations.
Based on the global goals, FAO has formulated five strategic objectives:
1. Contribute to the eradication of hunger, food insecurity and malnutrition
2. Make agriculture, forestry and fisheries more productive and sustainable
3. Reduce rural poverty
4. Enable more inclusive and efficient agricultural and food systems
5. Increase the resilience of livelihoods to threats and crises
The Strategic Framework also includes a sixth, broad objective on technical quality, knowledge and services (including cross-cutting themes) that is designed to cover FAO’s internal capability to deliver its strategic objectives. The objectives are in alignment with FAO’s commitment to working in partnerships.
In humanitarian crises, FAO’s main components are:
To help people to anticipate and prepare for crises; To respond fast to crises; To seek to reduce risks and address vulnerabilities.
The humanitarian operations are usually related to the 5th strategic objective which has the four following organizational outcomes (OO):
OO1 - countries and regions have legal, policy and institutional systems and regulatory frameworks for disaster and crisis risk management for agriculture, food and nutrition;
OO2 - countries and regions deliver regular information and trigger timely actions against potential, known and emerging threats to agriculture, food, and nutrition;
OO3 - countries apply prevention and impact mitigation measures that reduce risks for agriculture, food and nutrition;
OO4 - countries and regions affected by disasters and crises with impact on agriculture, food and nutrition are prepared for, and manage effective responses.
At the next level in the FAO Strategic Framework, there are a number of outputs pertinent to humanitarian action, such as:
Output 4.1: Humanitarian action effectively protect lives and livelihoods of farmers, herders, Fishers, forest- and tree-dependent communities and marginal groups in times of crises.
Output 3.1: Strategies and related interventions improve the resilience of livelihoods systems at risk through prevention and mitigation efforts that minimize the potential impacts of disasters and crises on agriculture food and nutrition at national, subnational and community levels.
Output 2.2: Improved capacities of countries and communities to identify monitor and evaluate risks; conduct needs assessment and response analysis; and act on impending threats to agriculture, nutrition, food security and food safety (and related public health issues).
Output 3.3: Conflict-sensitive programmes on agriculture, food and nutrition reduce the risks of localized conflicts relating to access to grazing, forest and farming lands, fishing grounds, water, trees and other natural resources.
As Sida support FAO’s operations through a variety of different projects in different contexts, this appraisal does not include an overarching results framework. In the annual follow up reading up to Sida’s conclusion on performance all individual project reports will be analysed and assessed.

title: Election support to Somaliland
description:
UNOPS har ansökt om finansiering på 5 000 000 SEK hos Sida för genomförandet av projektet "Joint Support to Somaliland National Electoral Commission" under perioden november 2020 till juli 2021. Den totala budgeten för det gemensamma stödet uppgår till $13 972 434, där Somalilands regering bidrar med $5 945 089, EU med $836 459 och Storbritannien med $870 000. Somalilands regering förväntas bidra med resterande finansiering.

Insatsen syftar till att stödja den nationella valkommissionen, National Electoral Commission (NEC), så att det kan genomföras fria och rättvisa parlamentsval och lokala val i Somaliland i maj 2021. Genom att insatsen direkt underlättar det stöd som riktas till givare till NEC via en multigivarmekanism, samt förstärker det pågående stöd som går via EU:s partnerskapsenhet, kommer insatsen att bidra till att stärka institutens legitimitet och demokratiseringen i och med att stödet syftar till att stärka valprocessen. Insatsen gäller specifikt: 1) Förberedande aktiviteter som fokuserar på operativa behov, inklusive etablering av kontor på distrikts- och regional nivå, bemanning, inköp av nödvändiga varor och tjänster samt utbildning av röstberättigade. 2) Röstregistrering och kortdistribution. 3) Aktiviteter som rör det juridiska ramverket, nominering av kandidater, registrering och granskning, inköp av valmaterial samt konfliktlösning.

title: CHD 2021-2023
description:
According to the project application the objective of the intervention is to promote high-level political dialogue processes as a means of contributing to improved peace and stability in Somalia. More specifically, to improve the political relationship between the Federal Government of Somalia (FGS) and the Federal Member States (FMS); build the capacity of MoIFAR and FMS line Ministries in the implementation of the National Reconciliation Framework (NRF); and help resolve inter and intra-Federal Members States relations through dialogue. The Somalia National Reconciliation Framework/Plan will be used as a guiding document to holds all these elements together.
The project aims to continue building on and consolidating achievements made through Sweden’s support to HD-facilitated work in Somalia to date. The project is based on three distinct but related dialogue streams or sub-objectives:
Promote high-level dialogue between the FGS and FMS through the MoIFAR-led National Reconciliation Framework (NRF) implementation process that helps resolve political tensions between them and paves the way for consensus building on key issues including federalism, constitutional review, forthcoming election and security amongst other state building concerns. Facilitate capacity building and provision of technical advice by both local and international expertise to MoIFAR and FMS line ministries in the implementation of the NRF that informs and shapes the process while improving working relations between the FGS and FMS. Support dialogue processes for the FMS that helps them resolve inter and intra-state disputes that affects them helping in the building of more harmonious and mutually beneficial relationships.
These political dialogue processes in combination provide important building blocks for increased political stability in Somalia. The political developments in Somalia since the inception of the FGS have highlighted the importance of consultation and ownership by Somali leadership in order for the solutions to be sustained, achieve the necessary impact and stability on the ground. This project seeks to advance the objectives with the following activities:
Promote high-level dialogue between the Federal Government of Somalia and the Federal Member States by: Continuing to work with senior representatives of MoIFAR at Federal and FMS levels as well as key advisors on reconciliation in the President/Prime Minister’s office in reaching out to key high-level representatives to engage in the dialogue between the FGS and FMS; Working with MOIFAR using the NRF as an entry point in partnership with FBA and UN REFS to create an FGS-FMS inter-ministerial forum that will ultimately become the operational/implementation arm of the NRF process; Undertaking shuttle dialogue between key actors to develop strategies for getting buy-in and ownership of the top leadership at both the FGS and FMS level on the federal structure and other state building matters; Facilitating and convening dialogue between the FGS and FMS leadership in order to resolve conflict issues between them such as constitutional review, elections, federalism, security and agree on mechanisms to address any new arising matters; Providing technical advice and expertise in the dialogue processes as well as capacity building support for key stakeholders in thematic areas on economic, political and social issues such as resource and power-sharing, reconciliation and conflict resolution amongst others;
Expected outcomes of objective 1:
Expected outcomes of the 2021-2023 project: - Increased confidence amongst the parties’, evidenced by their willingness and enthusiasm to participate in FGS-FMS dialogue;
- Correspondence of action by FGS-FMS in relation to implementation of the Somalia National Reconciliation Framework and other national issues;   - Build consensus among the international community which supports this initiative on how best to support the FGS-FMS relationship building; 
- Dialogue begins to improve the relationship between the FGS and FMS and helps to manage tensions on emerging issues; 
- A forum is established that allows the FGS and FMS discuss and reach agreements on critical and long-standing critical issues that will determine the relationship between both the FGS and the FMS, going forward
Facilitate capacity building and provision of technical advice by both local and international expertise to MoIFAR and FMS line ministries in the implementation of the National Reconciliation Framework by:  Further consolidate the relationships established and effectively implement the resolutions reached in the course of the March 2020 HD-organized Study Tour to Rwanda to move forward the NRF implementation process; Continuing to collaborate with senior representatives of MoIFAR at Federal and FMS levels as well as key advisors at the President/Prime Minister’s office and other identified partners in implementation of the NRF;
Expected outcomes of objective 2: 
- Providing capacity building, technical advice and expertise in implementation of the NRF as well as in other identified related thematic areas.
- Sustained dialogue on the NRF implementation is the main connector between the FGS and FMS that contributes to enhancement of their working relationships.
- MoIFAR in Mogadishu and line Ministries in the FMS discuss and agree on joint action and messaging to achieve both national and state-specific reconciliation needs.
- Support tension management measures to cope with any emerging issues between MoIFAR and the FMS line ministries.
Support FMS dialogue processes geared towards helping them resolve inter and intrastate disputes Shuttle diplomacy efforts between key actors to foster dialogue between leaders of the FMS to address existing or arising issues as a tension management and confidence building strategy, as well as ensure continued communication on areas of concern; Providing technical advice and support to FMS government officials on substantive issues of conflict between and within them and develop options for advancing these issues through dialogue; Organizing and facilitating dialogue sessions for designated representatives to discuss and reach agreement on how to address issues of conflict; Convene follow-up interactions and engagements on agreed issues as required.
Expected outcomes of objective 3: 
Expected outcomes of 2021-2023 project: - Dialogue between the FGS and the FMS sets a solid foundation for a genuine national reconciliation process to take place.
-  Dialogue begins to improve the relationship between the centre and the periphery and helps to manage tensions on emerging issues.
 - A forum is established that allows the centre and peripheries to discuss and reach agreement in long standing national issues.
Coordination between different actors: 
There are several actors working in the same area and to clarify the roles between the different actors HD has specified the areas within the objectives where they see that they will have a leading role in contribution to the overall objectives: 
Objective 1:
- Support confidence building measures that increase trust and cooperation between the FGS and FMS to engage in dialogue on national reconciliation and other issues of national interest;
- Contribute ideas on how best the international community can support national reconciliation through support the FGS-FMS on elections, constitutional review process, power-sharing amongst other federalisation and national issues.
Objective 2: 
- Contribute to good working relationships between MoIFAR and the FMS on the NRF and other issues of mutual interest; 
- Build and expand the MoIFAR network of “friends” at both the national and FMS levels; 
- Enhance the capacity of MoIFAR and FMS counterparts on technical issues relating to reconciliation, mediation and dialogue, resource sharing and other national issues.
Objective 3: 
- Discussions help in shaping and reaching agreement on a design/mechanism for a successful Somali National Reconciliation process; 
- Contribution to the further development of the Somalia Federalization process.
In the objectives above Sida will expect HD to take a leading role in coordinating with other projects to avoid duplication of work and ensure effectivenss. A dialogue issue has been added to ensure follow-up.

title: SOMGEP - Transition
description: Working in Somaliland, Puntland and Galmudug states of Somalia, this 4.5 year project entitled SOMGEP II focuses on supporting current cohort of girls under GEC to access quality education beyond primary level, transitioning into either formal secondary school or an accelerated learning track. CARE is the lead implementer with ADRA as a sub. Key outputs are the following: -Increase access to post-primary options -Promote positive shifts on gender and social norms at community, parental and individual girl level -Improve quality of education at primary and post-primary levels -Improve school conditions in close collaboration with communities -Strengthen

title: Adolescent Girls' Education (AGES)
description: The project will work with two groups of adolescent girls age 10-19 totaling 40,000 girls: (1) Girls who have dropped out of early primary grades without attaining sufficient numeracy and literacy skills, most of whom are involved in paid or unpaid domestic work. Older girls are likely to be already married. (2) Girls who have never enrolled in school, extremely vulnerable to early marriage or already adolescent wives and mothers. Most are involved in casual work and have limited time and interest to pursue regular education options. , the project will work with the government, communities and education providers to offer three tailored pathways for girls to access quality education over a period of 4 years: - An 11-month alternative basic education (ABE) course will enable young adolescents (girls and boys) who dropped out or have never been to school to reach a Grade 4 level, become fluent readers and fully numerate, and acquire basic life skills (financial literacy, leadership skills, communication and negotiation).

title: Somali Programme
description:
Decentralisation in Somaliland is still in its early stages. While District Councils are mandated to provide services to citizens, there is still an unclear delineation of roles and responsibilities, as most sectors are (in practice) not yet decentralised from the line ministries and in many cases delivery been taken over by NGOs. Furthermore, there is a palpable mismatch between the responsibilities allocated to districts and the (financial and human) resources they have.

The Association of Local Government Authorities of Somaliland (ALGASL) was established in 2006 by the mayors of 10 district councils. ALGASL aims to build strong local governments and support decentralisation, benefiting local communities, including marginalized groups such as women, youth and IDPs. At present, ALGASL has 10 paying members out of the 23 districts with elected district councils. Though ALGASL has potential, the association is constrained by a lack of human and financial resources, which hinders its ability to fulfill its mandate and attract additional members.

If strengthened, ALGASL can play a pivotal role in working towards more legitimate local governments, because of its mandate to lobby and advocate for the interests of districts and to build their capacity. It is a highly relevant linchpin between central and local government, can provide nationwide outreach and can promote exchange of experience among districts through its platform function.

title: Inclusive Decisions At Local Level (IDEAL)
description: IDEAL is a programme by VNG International that works on the involvement of citizens in local governance in seven countries facing fragility or conflict. The participation of citizens contributes to inclusive decision-making. It improves local governance and the delivery of basic services. It makes local governance more sustainable and increases welfare and stability. Our drive and expertise is to support local governments in building bridges with all their citizens - including marginalised groups. Being part of VNG (the Association of Netherlands Municipalities) we benefit from over a hundred years of experience in the field of local governance. IDEAL targets local governments and local government associations in 7 countries: Burundi, Mali, Palestinian Territories, Rwanda, Somalia, South Sudan and Uganda.

title: EC SWS Drought Response - SomRep2
description: SWS Emergency Drought Response Funding - WV Somalia, with DEC funding for the first 6 months of the project. "Drought recovery and building resilience to natural disasters is a high priority in Somalia, especially now in 2017, that a severe drought is hitting the country. Households and communities must recover, adapt and diversify their livelihoods and asset base in order to cope effectively during both harsh dry seasons and disaster episodes. SomReP’s approach acknowledges the need to recover from shock quickly and its programming seeks to promote the local absorptive and adaptive capacity of households and communities. While promoting drought recovery, the program also builds institutional capacity, strengthens the natural resource management that underpins resilience livelihood, and prevents loss of livelihood assets through proactive early action."

Focusing on improved regulatory frameworks, enhanced public service delivery, and civic engagement, SDC contributes to enhanced state legitimacy, peacebuilding and more equitable access to public service well-being for all citizens, aiming thereby at more stability in the Horn of Africa.

description: The Trade and Investment Advocacy Fund 2 Plus (TAF 2+) provides on-demand technical assistance to developing countries to participate in trade and investment negotiations. The Fund, managed by AECOM and Saana Consulting Ltd, runs from 2017-2023. TAF 2+ takes a targeted approach with different windows of support being provided to selected developing countries and select HMG Departments.  Negotiations Window (window 1), targeting priority negotiations and grantees.  Strategic Window (window 2), broader support before or immediately after negotiations.  DFID Country Office Window (window 3), providing technical trade advice to DFID Country Offices. Programme website - http://taf2plus.com/

title: Health and Education Sector Development through Skills and Knowledge Transfer in South Central Somalia
description:
The project aims at improving the capacity of public sector health and education institutions to provide quality services with special focus on vulnerable groups: women children and youth through skills and knowledge transfer by the Somali diaspora. The ov
erall objective of the project is to contribute to stabilization in South Central Somalia and Puntland through increasing access to basic services (health and education) and creating employment opportunities for the youth including women. In addition young
 Somalis will be placed in internship positions under the supervision of the diaspora experts at relevant institutions. The project trains health and education sector professionals to produce quality public services in health and education and to administe
r the resources of the sectors. The trainers are diaspora experts especially Finnish diaspora who work and share their expertise in the sectors.The Mid-Term Evaluation which was finalized in August 2018 showed that results have been gained in both health a
nd education sectors. For example the intake of patients at Yardimeli Hospital in Mogadishu has increased significantly in a short period of time from around 800 patients in July 2017 to around 4000 in March 2018. Moreover the number of assisted births inc
reased substantially. The diaspora experts placed at the Ministry of Education were successful in supporting the organizational reform and writing key strategic planning documents for the sector. According to the Mid-Term Evaluation the project was very re
levant in filling the gaps and specialized needs in the institutions. According to all participants both local and the diaspora the project was successful in producing sustainable results in skills and knowledge. The implementing partner is the Internation
al Organisation for Migration (IOM). From 2015 to 2019 Finland has supported the project with 4 420 000 EUR. From 2019 to 2021 the total budget for the second phase funded by Finland is 5 400 000 EUR. The budget is disbursed as follows: 1 MEUR in 2019; 24 
MEUR in 2020; 2 MEUR in 2021.

title: Maailmanpankin yhteisrahoitusohjelma Somaliassa
description:
World Bank's Multi-Partner Fund (MPF) supports Somalia's stabilization and peacebuilding by strengthening Somalia's governance and the management of the state's revenues (including taxation) as well as by reviving the country's economy and the private sect
or to allow increased state revenues through taxation and to provide resources for extended and improved public services. In the project level the funded projects focus around four thematic priority areas which include government's key functions; productiv
e sectors and employment; infrastructure development; as well as management of natural resources and resilience. For example the Fund can support the payment of Somalia's government officials' salaries and improve the public financial management systems; b
oost the productivity and the value chains of potential productive sectors and improve youth employment (allowing also greater tax revenues); improve the infrastructure and therefroe improve the productivity among else in the energy sector; and strengthen 
the resilience of selected groups and professions such as cattle herders/pastoralists.The Fund also supports one of Finland's priority sectors the Health sector by strengthening health governance's salary payment and financial management systems as well as
 by supporting the governance capacity in the sector.The Fund operates in close partnership with the Federal Government of Somalia as well as with the donors and international agencies through the New Deal framework and through its aid infrastructure Somal
ia Development and Reconstruction Facility (SDRF) offering peace and statebuilding support to the Somali transition process. Finland together with other international partners has committed itself to work increasingly through the New Deal structures.Finlan
d supports the MPF over the period of 2016-2019 with 4MEUR which is disbursed as follows: 2016: 2MEUR 2018: 1MEUR 2019: 1MEUR.

title: Public-Private-People: Joint and Inclusive Effort Against Tuberculosis in Somalia
description:
The project builds on the previous TB intervention implemented by LSV. However in order to increase effectiveness totally new strategies will be applied.TB continues to be an essential health problem in Somalia. The disease hasn't been beaten yet but rathe
r new problems emerge such as multi-drug resistant forms of TB resulting in much more complex treatment regimens and bigger danger to the population.LSV will continue to diagnose and treat TB patients in Hargeisa and Mogadishu. As a new strategy the privat
e sector health care providers (clinics and pharmacies) and local communities will be engaged in the effort in a systematic way in order to strengthen a holistic public-private-people partnership approach to tackling the disease. In addition collaboration 
with the local maternity and child health facility network will be strengthened. The overall objective is to contribute to the reduction of TB burden and suffering in Somalia. The immediate objectives of the project include 1) To increase TB awareness and 
participation of communities in TB control. 2) To increase TB awareness and participation of private practitioners and pharmacists in TB control in. 3) To diagnose and treat patients at two TB centers according to WHO's DOTS protocol. 4) To provide TB cult
ure services and drug susceptibility tests (DST) for suspected MDR cases.Regarding the cross-cutting themes the project will empower women and facilitate their access to TB services. In addition the project will reduce inequality by providing an access to 
TB services for internally displaced persons (IDPs). When it comes to climate proofing there are no negative impacts on environment. For example thanks to community DOTS there will be less daily traveling to TB Centers.The main project partners include NGO
 called PSR and National TB Programs (NTPs). LSV will strengthen their capacity in all the fields described above.The main beneficiaries include local people of Hargeisa Mogadishu and nomads living in nearby areas who have TB or belong to risk groups. The 
project will help the poorest of the poor. For example many cases are found among people who suffer from malnutrition.

title: Hiil hooyo - aitiysterveyden edistamishanke
description:
Hiil hooyo is a multi-actor joint project addressing maternal healthcare in Somaliland and Puntland. The key development problem is high maternal mortality having multiple negative effects. Maternal mortality rate in the project areas is one of the highest
 in the world. The project seeks to enhance women's right and the right of persons with disabilities to maternal healthcare. The project started in 2017 with a pilot phase and the new phase aims to make the results sustainable.The main outcomes are:1. Skil
ls and motivation of healthcare workers improved2. Number of mothers and children attending MCHs increased3. Attendance and accessibility of persons with disabilities to MCHs increased4. Partner universities able to conduct independently e-learning program
 in maternal healthcare and students benefitted from the developed materialThe main outputs and activities include:- 240 healthcare workers passed in-service training on maternal healthcare; 4 trainings- 10 000 persons reached by awareness raising programs
; village meetings school classes media campaigns home visits fathers? clubs- 460 persons trained on the rights of persons with disabilities; training of trainers workshops- 120 university students passed e-learning program in maternal healthcare teachers 
trained and partner universities networking; e-course for students on-line training for teachers joint meetingsThe project is implemented in 10 districts in 3 areas. For the implementation the FSN has 6 NGO partners of which 3 its member organizations in F
inland and 5 university partners of which 2 (Diak and Xamk) in Finland. In addition the Disability Partnership Finland (DPF) offers expertize for disability issues. The innovative cooperative model enforces the civil society and enhances stability.The bene
ficiaries of the project include healthcare workers pregnant and breastfeeding mothers with their families persons with disabilities university lecturers and students students in secondary schools the NGO partners and indirectly communities in general in t
he project areas with an estimated population of 15 million.

title: HALO/Humanitaarinen miinatoiminta Somaliassa
description:
HALO?s project will support and strengthen Somalia?s security stability and development through humanitarian mine action and stockpile destruction. HALO?s project seeks to 1) contribute to the human security and reduce civilian accidents and casualties by 
limiting the impact and proliferation of explosive items 2) contribute to the peace dividend and assist fragile communities in their own efforts to reinstate a working and stable society and 3) reduce poverty and hunger by removing blockage to high priorit
y infrastructure water access and roads. The project takes place in two phases: First completing the manual clearance of Somaliland at which point mine action in Somaliland will become completely owned funded and implemented by national authorities with su
fficient capacity to tackle any residual tasking. Finland has supported this project since 2003. Second HALO will seek and destroy community held or abandoned stockpiles of ammunition held outside of state control across their area of operations in Souther
n Somalia. The primary beneficiaries of the project are local populations in areas where HALO will conduct mine clearance and stockpile destruction. Finland will support HALO?s project in Somalia during 2017-2020 with one million euros.

title: UNFPA Somalia Wellbeing of Women and Girls
description:
Support to the UN Population Fund's (UNFPA) country programme continues Finland's strong contribution for the development of Somalia's reproductive maternal and child health care services. UNFPA has been among the three UN agencies that have been involved 
in the UN Joint Nutrition and Health Programme in Somalia (JHNP) which focused on the development of maternal and child health services. Finland supported the implementation of the programme for 15.5MEUR between 2014-2016. JHNP has provided services for an
 area covering half of Somalia's population. It has reached good results having significantly contributed to the reduction of maternal and infant mortality. Through JHNP UNFPA has supported the provision of maternal sexual and reproductive health services 
as well as contributed to improving their quality. UNFPA has supported the running of 135 maternal clinics; the training of midwifes in 15 midwiferies throughout Somalia; the provision of training on reproductive health for over 600 health care professiona
ls; as well as the provision of technical assistance to the ministries of health to support their capacity building including their work on health sector strategic development. As JHNP is coming to an end in early-2017 UNFPA continues the work to develop t
he reproductive maternal and child health care in Somalia according to its mandate.UNFPA country strategy for Somalia for 2011-2016 has been extended for one year to cover also 2017. Its overall objective is to improve the wellbeing of Somali people. The c
ountry strategy aims to achieve this through reducing maternal mortality and through supporting the realization of reproductive rights and services. In addition the strategy supports gender equality and combats gender-based violence as well as strengthens 
the Somali statistical systems and promotes evidence-based planning and policy design.Three particular priority areas have been identified for 2017:1.Increased provision of comprehensive sexual and reproductive health services (around 50% of the annual bud
get for 2017)2.Promotion of gender equality and prevention of gender-based violence (around 25% of the 2017 budget)3.Strengthened national capacity on use of quality disaggregated data for evidence-based planning and policy design on population and develop
ment issues (around 25% of the 2017 budget)Finland supports the implementation of the UNFPA Somalia country strategy for 2011-2017 for 2 million euros.

title: FCA: Supporting national and local level reconciliation in Somalia
description:
Somalia is recovering from decades of war and collapse of state structures. The core state functions are now operating and state formation is underway. The legitimacy of the state however is still weak. Conflicts and violence remain a significant challenge
. The biggest threat is still Al Shabaab but violent conflicts between clans and militias as well as organized crime are also common. The weak security situation hampers development efforts and attempts to address the difficult humanitarian situation.Finn 
Church Aid (FCA) and the Network for Religious and Traditional Peacemakers have been active in mediation and local-level democratisation and institution building in Somalia for several years. In 2017 an expert was seconded to the Ministry for Interior Fede
ral Affairs and Reconciliation (MoIFAR) at the request of the Somali government. The expert has held a key position in the team in charge of drafting the strategy for reconciliation. During the years 2018-2019 the Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland ha
s supported national and local-level reconciliation processes through FCA and the Network. The first phase of the project saw the development of a nation-wide National Reconciliation Framework based on consultations with state and civil society actors. In 
February 2019 the draft was validated at a national conference in Mogadishu. Altogether 300 representatives from the federal government federal member states and civil society took part in the conference. The National Reconciliation Framework was approved 
by the Cabinet in in March 2019. It has become one of the key priorities of the Somali government and especially MoIFAR.The second phase of the project supports MoIFAR in the implementation of the national reconciliation process while advancing the partici
pation of women and youth in the process. The project also includes support to local-level reconciliation. Finland supports the second phase of the project with 461 384 euros. The project will be implemented over a period of 12 months in 2019-2020.

title: Finnpartnership programme
description: Long term partnership with a local company / organisation (e.g. joint venture; subcontractor, import or other contract agreement )

title: Mustaqbaldoon
description:
The project contributes to the development problem of the vulnerability of the youth which is manifested in youth unemployment and limited access to income causing risky survival strategies such as informal quasi-legal or illegal activities and as a conseq
uence social problems like violence early sexual activity and a range of economic physical and psychological risks.The principal outcomes of the project are 1) Strengthened Civil Society and Local Administration 2) Increased motivation of youth to contribu
te to the society and 3) Increased economic empowerment of youth. The central activities include capacitating the local CSOs and public administration turning the risky survival strategies of youth to healthy ones and 3) training youth to recognize local i
ncome generation opportunities instead of leaving the country.  Developing countries? own economies have generated more jobs livelihood opportunities and well-being is the priority area of Finland's development policy the project is aimed at contributing t
o. Somalia is ranked as one of the bottom five countries in terms of gender inequality and therefore positive discrimination and affirmative measures will be taken to enhance the participation of young women and girls and to raise awareness about their par
ticular needs. The project aims to reduce inequality by emphasizing the rights of all youth as full and equal members of the communities where they live. Project respects climate sustainability too.The project capacitates CSOs and public administration to 
work with private sector according to multi-stakeholder approach. Helsinki Deaconess Institute?s Vamos services is acknowledged in a national level as a unique concept to support vulnerable youth's access to education and employment. The same concept will 
be used together with cooperation partners Y-PEER in Hargeisa and Gedo Development in Gedo. The principal beneficiaries of the project are the youth (15-35 years) who have dropped out from education and employment.

title: Human rights based approach to strengthening community mental health services in Somaliland
description:
The project tackles Somaliland's high burden of mental health problems coupled with a weak mental health care infrastructure which is not able to provide high-quality mental health services from a human rights perspective.The project aims to increase the a
ccess of people to community-based mental health services;promote the adoption of a human rights based approach to mental health in public/private mental health services;and to increase public awareness on mental health issues to decrease the stigma and di
scrimination against people with mental disorders in Somaliland.A special focus is on women/girls and vulnerable groups (SGBV survivorsIDPsdisabled personsprisoners).To support the sustainability of the intervention and to promote the long-term development
 of the mental health care infrastructure in Somalilandthe project will increase the capacity of health care officials to promote mental health from a human rights perspective to coordinate mental health services.The main cross-cutting themes of the projec
t are:health promotionhuman rightsgender equality and good governance.The main activities are: training community mental health workers and social workers to provide community mental health servicesprovision of out-patient treatmentsupporting the capacity 
of the MOH to plan and implement mental health services and policyand raising awareness on mental health.The main beneficiaries of the project are people in Somaliland suffering from mental disorderstheir families and communitiesvulnerable groups in need o
f mental health care civil society and health officials.PSR is well positioned to carry out the project with 30+ years of experience in health development projects also of mental health projects in post-conflict contexts.PSR has long-term project experienc
e in Somalia/Somaliland (2006-) and good local networks.The local partner GAVO is a well-respected local NGO with long-term experience in mental health projects.The Finnish partners FiPSR and Disability Partnership Finland have long-term experience that co
ntributes closely to the project.The project contributes to the FSA project in Jubaland and collaborates with the HDI project in Somaliland

title: Fighting TB in Somalia: public-private partnerships and inclusive communities
description:
The project is founded on PSR's previous projects in Somalia which have developed new strategies to tackle tuberculosis (TB) ? especially in community and private sector engagement. A special focus will be placed on women and vulnerable community members: 
disabled persons IDPs and prisoners. Tuberculosis is a central health problem in Somalia. The increase of multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is a global threat ? fighting against MDR-TB in Somalia benefits all countries. Another central problem is 
the low treatment coverage rate of about 37% leaving far too many cases untreated further transmitting tuberculosis to others. The impact targets of the project are to: a) tackle multi-drug resistant tuberculosis; and b) increase the tuberculosis case dete
ction rate. The long-term objective of the project is to contribute to the reduction of the tuberculosis burden in Somalia with the following means:1. Increase the access of women and vulnerable groups to TB services (such as disabled personsIDPs and priso
ners)2. Increase TB referrals from the private sector3. Improve the quality of TB treatment in both the public and private sector4. Improve the quality of TB laboratory work.The central partners of the project are the National Tuberculosis Programmes of So
maliland and Somalia. PSR has a central role in developing the national tuberculosis diagnostic infrastructure in Somalia. The project will support the National TB Reference Laboratories in Somaliland and South-Central Somalia as well as will treatment of 
tuberculosis patients in 3 clinics in Hargeisa and Mogadishu. These clinics will develop innovative community public and private sector engagement models to increase case detection improve treatment quality and to increase public awareness and decrease sti
gma/discrimination. The clinics will also provide HIV services and nutritional support for malnourished patients (with WFP).Together with the local administration the tuberculosis clinics will be transformed into health centers providing specialized tuberc
ulosis services by the end of 2022 to support integration with basic health services and sustainability after the project has ended.

Support to this programme will increase access to sexual and reproductive rights and health services. The programme will also contribute to addressing gender inequality, as well as production of key population data to be used for evidence based programming in Somalia. This will improve women’s well-being, enhance family planning and, as a consequence, increase stability in the region, which is in the Swiss interest.

reported_by: Affaires étrangères, Commerce et Développement Canada (MAECD)
title: Crise El Niño - Soutien global en Afrique et en Haïti - FAO 2016
description: October 2016 - The humanitarian crisis arising from the 2015-2016 El Niño is continuing to deepen, with the United Nations estimating that more than 60 million people are now affected worldwide. While international donors, including Canada, have already stepped up with humanitarian assistance to save lives and protect livelihoods, a significant funding gap persists and humanitarian needs are expected to escalate well into 2017. The impact is most pronounced in Ethiopia, which experienced its worst drought in 50 years, leaving 10 million people in need of emergency food assistance. In the Americas, Haiti is one of the most affected countries, with a third consecutive year of drought, exacerbated by El Niño, leaving more than 3.6 million people food insecure. Similar impacts are being felt around the globe. To date, twenty three countries have appealed for help to meet critical needs, including food, agricultural support, and water and sanitation.  With GAC's support, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) is promoting early recovery and resilience building in some of the countries worst hit by El Niño, including Ethiopia, Haiti, Malawi, Somalia, Sudan, Swaziland and Zimbabwe. Although specific programming differs based on the context in each country, FAO is protecting the lives and livelihoods of vulnerable groups, such as subsistence farmers and pastoralists, with agricultural inputs and livestock support.

implementing: FAO - Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
programming: Affaires étrangères, Commerce et Développement Canada

title: A Civil Society Organised Crime Observatory For East And Southern Africa
description: The creation of a Civil Society Observatory for Southern and Eastern Africa was intended as a contribution to building an evidence base and capacity to counter illicit financial flows. This is vital in a region where institutional levels of corruption and governance failures have held back development, economic growth and severely impacted the lives of ordinary citizens.  Growing levels of violence domestically and across borders have also exacerbated levels of insecurity.

reported_by: Affaires étrangères, Commerce et Développement Canada (MAECD)
title: Assistance d'urgence au Nigéria et en Somalie - FAO 2018
description: L’Organisation des Nations Unies pour l’alimentation et l’agriculture (FAO) vise à développer, protéger et rétablir des moyens de subsistance viables de sorte que l’intégrité des sociétés tributaires de l’agriculture, de l’élevage du bétail, de la pêche et d’autres ressources naturelles ne soit pas menacée par des crises. La FAO contribue à la relance accélérée et plus durable de la production locale d’aliments, tout en préservant les acquis en matière de développement, en réduisant la dépendance à l’égard de l’aide et en favorisant l’autonomie des populations touchées par les crises.  Avec le soutien d’AMC et d’autres donateurs, la FAO dispense de l’aide d’urgence à plus de 4,3 millions de personnes touchées par un conflit et une grave insécurité alimentaire au Nigéria et en Somalie. Les activités du projet incluent : 1) la distribution d’intrants agricoles comme des semences de produits nutritifs, des outils ainsi que de matériel de pêche; 2) des transferts de fonds et des activités de travail contre rémunération; 3) des mesures de soutien pour le bétail et des intrants vétérinaires, comme des vaccins, des blocs de sels minéraux, des semences de cultures fourragères, des réservoirs à eau pliables et de l’eau transportée par camion-citerne; 4) de la formation en techniques agricoles; et 5) le soutien de mesures d’urgence de contrôle due la chenille légionnaire d’automne.

implementing: FAO - Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
programming: Affaires étrangères, Commerce et Développement Canada

title: DEC COVID-19 Appeal 2020
description: Protecting vulnerable communities from the spread and impact of the COVID-19 virus in Somalia, South Sudan and Yemen

title: Maternity Clinic and Training Project
description:
Long-running conflict has destroyed the infrastructure of the Somali state and the country has one of the worst health indicators in the world. The high-risk groups are 2.4 million children under age 5 and more than 3 million women of child-bearing age. Ac
cording to WHO the maternal mortality ratio is 732 per 100 000 live births although most of the maternal deaths would be preventable. Rebuilding the health sector is challenged by a shortage of professional staff financial resources and effective governanc
e and NGOs have played a key role in providing with these services. African Care?s Maternity Clinic and Training project has since its start in 2012 supported the development of the FinSom maternity clinic together with the local partner VMDSO. Results sho
w that the service of the clinic has decreased maternal mortality rate prevalence of tetanus raised awareness about exclusive breast feeding and FGM. The clinic is well-known in Afgoye and surrounding areas and a vital source of quality maternal health car
e for both expectant mothers and the community. Hence the maternal health care services are continued also in the continuation phase of the project.The project at hand seeks to further enhance the capacity and services of the partner and the clinic so that
 eventually maternal health services could be provided without development cooperation funding. This is done by investing in the education and training of the VMDSO staff and health workers and monitoring the long-term impact of the trainings. Simultaneous
ly invaluable information on the key challenges and development needs will be mapped out and used for future trainings.  Also the support of the sexual violence victims will be intensified. It will be expanded to an in-person counselling in addition to the
 telephone support. Open-access seminars and family counselling are likewise continued and further intensified. Seminars about gender equality family planning and gender-based violence work to dismantle unequal social structures through open dialogue. Proj
ect's beneficiaries are women in labour children victims of sexual violence clinic?s personnel and partner organization VMDSO.

title: Sahansaho ? Somalian aavikoitumista vastaan
description:
The key development problem which the project aims to find solutions to is the desertification leading to lack of livelihoods poverty and forced migration. The objective is sustainable use of natural resources and secured livelihood in the project areas. T
he project started in 2012 and it has been planned for 10 years. This continuation project will be its 4th and final phase.The outcomes of 2019-2022 will be:1. Environmental centers developed into regional hubs2. Educational institutions and trainers have 
expertise to provide environmental education3. Resilience of local communities to climate change and drought improved4. Implementation of policies related to natural resource management (NRM)The outputs will be: 1.1. Seedlings of locally successful species
 produced planted distributed and sold per year 1.2. Seed collection stands established and local availability of the seeds of the most important species secured 1.3. Operating models for the environmental centers developed 2.1. Trainers trained and traini
ng material produced 2.2. Training materials and research opportunities provided to universities and environmental education material provided to teachers 3.1. Charcoal and firewood consumption reduced in local communities 3.2. Agroforestry practices and s
oil and water conservation techniques adopted in local communities 4.1.  Network of the environmental actors built and environmental efforts and common initiatives coordinated at all project sites 4.2.  Policy reviews and briefs produced for policy dialogu
e with ministries of environment and implementation of environmental policies startedThe project is implemented at 3 sites in Somalia with the FSN's four partners in Finland and three partners in Somalia. The innovative cooperative model enforces the civil
 society in Somalia and creates new networks  that also promote peace and stability.The beneficiaries are local communities authorities and educational institutions among others.

title: Ramaad - environment relief project in Somalia
description:
Ramaad is a joint project coordinated by the Finnish Somalia Network  (FSN) with its partners addressing the sustainable use and management  of the natural resources in Somalia and desertification that leads to  loss of livelihoods poverty and forced migra
tion. The project started  in 2014 and is planned for 10 years. This is its 4th and final phase.  The long-term objective is sustainable use and management of natural  resources and secured livelihood in the project areas.The outcomes are:1.    3 environme
ntal centers developed into regional hubs with own income2.    Environmental education and awareness increased in project areas3.    Charcoal and firewood consumption reduced by making energy saving  stoves locally available4.    Capacity of administration
s to formulate and implement  environmental policies has increased and implementation of the  policies has startedThe main outputs are:- 30 000 seedlings of locally successful species produced planted  distributed and sold- 90 seed collection stands establ
ished and local availability of the  seeds of the most important species secured- Operating models for the 3 environmental centers developed  partners' capacity to carry out business activities built and  feasibility study for stove fabrication workshops p
repared- Environmental awareness of the local communities and environmental  education in schools increased- 3 stove manufacturing workshops established and 18 craftsmen trained- Environmental efforts and common initiatives coordinated- Implementation of e
nvironmental policies at district and local level startedThe project is implemented in three areas in southern and central  Somalia with the FSN's four partners in Finland and three partner NGOs  in Somalia. The innovative cooperative model enforces the ci
vil  society and enhances stability. The project areas are:1. Guriel and Dhusamareeb Galmudug2. El-Adde Gedo/Jubbaland3. Afmadow Lower Jubba/Jubbaland

title: Somalian sananvapauden journalismin ja julkisen palvelun tukihanke
description:
The continuation phase of Vikes Somalia project supports the Somali national TV channel to develop towards editorially an independent public service broadcaster and assists the national journalist union to become a representative trade union of media worke
rs across Somalia.By providing journalist training and technical support the project seeks to 1) improve the production process and quality of news and other programmes at Somali National Television (SNTV) 2) improve the awareness of media rights and respo
nsibilities and safety of Somali journalists and 3) improve professional skills of women journalists.Project activities include the introduction of regular children?s programme production at SNTV. The project will support the preparation of a journalist co
de of conduct and the drafting of a by-law on public service broadcasting.About 300 journalists across the country will be trained in practical journalism skills media rights and security and professional ethics.The project is based on peer learning. Journ
alists are trained by more experienced Finnish and Somali journalists. Local technicians are trained by experienced Finnish technical experts. Local cameramen and video editors are trained by experienced visiting multimedia professionals from Finland.Main 
cooperation partners are Somali Ministry of Information and the National Union of Somali Journalists. Joint training activities will also be arranged with Somaliland Journalists Association (SOLJA).

title: Somaliland Health Sector Support (MIDA Finnsom IV)
description:
IOM MIDA Finnsom IV project focuses on contributing to improved health outcomes in Somaliland and particularly its remote regions. To achieve this the project supports the capacity of public sector institutions to provide quality health services. Three out
puts have been defined:1.) Local health professionals have skills/capacity to deliver quality health services2.) Local health training institutions have improved competence and ability to train local health professionals 3.) Ministry of Health has increase
d capacity to steer manage and coordinate the health sector The Somali diaspora experts particularly the Finnish Somali diaspora experts are the actors in the capacity building efforts. They train the local health professionals and participate in developin
g strategies plans standards and curricula for health sector. Particular attention is given to women's and child health. In the long term the project is expected to contribute to better health outcomes for Somaliland population and especially the health ou
tcomes for women and children.The first Finnish funded MIDA project was initiated already in 2008. The project has been evaluated twice and the findings suggest that the project has significantly strengthened public health institutions? ability to provide 
quality services in Somaliland. The findings and recommendations of evaluations have been duly notified in the planning of the Finnsom IV phase: For example the project now focuses on the more remote regions in Somaliland where service provision is poorer 
than in the capital Hargeisa. Similarly following the recommendations the length of the assignments of diaspora experts has been increased for Phase IV.To support the implementation of the project the National Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) also im
plements tailored trainings for the Ministry of Health.The duration of the Phase IV is four years from March 2017 until February 2021. The budget for the project is 4 300 000 Euros. Somalia is considered an LDC country.

title: Mobiili Terveyskaliniikka - Daryeel hanke Somaliassa Afmadowssa
description:
The Daryeel Mobile Health Clinic ?project aims at providing preventive and basic health care services to rural areas outside of Afmadow town in Jubaland Somalia. The project is executed by the Finland-Somalia Association (FSA) with partner NGO SAHDA and th
e Jubaland Ministry of Health. The project is a continuation of the Maternal and Child Health Services Clinic ?project that the FSA has ran since 2011 in Afmadow town. Based on an agreement with the Jubaland Ministry of Health the FSA has been asked to swi
tch its foces to more remote villages through a mobile clinic. The mobile clinic is to start its operations in 2018 depending on permission from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Finland. With this application the project plan is to continue the Mobile He
alth Clinic through 2019-2020 a total of three years.The main development problem that the project aims to solve is the poor access to preventive and basic health care in the Afmadow area in Jubaland Somalia. The project aims to take health services close 
to remote communities where it is difficult to get access to basic healthcare and where travelling is a challenge. By curing and providing basic health services in remote locations the project contrib-utes to creating a healthier community and society with
 people who are able to work for their own livelihoods. In this context the project contributes significantly to achieving the UN?s Sustainable Development Goals. The development impact that the project strives for is to increase the wellbeing of the commu
nities in the project area and to decrease the number of diseases and illnesses.The mobile clinic concept includes three core outputs:1. Supporting existing healthcare by providing health services in suburbs nearby villages and towns2. Providing supportive
 services in first aid family reproductive services and interventions reducing infectious diseases in the target villages3. Reducing travelling for health services from the towns as well as building the competence of the local community in health particula
rly by giving tools and knowledge to local midwives.

title: IOM Enhancing the Institutional Capacity of the Immigration and Naturalization Directorate of Somalia
description:
Somalia is recovering from decades of war and collapse of state structures. The core state functions are now recovering but the legitimacy and capacity of the state are still weak. Conflicts and violence remain a significant challenge. The prolonged confli
ct has resulted in porous air sea and land-border management providing a thriving conduit for Transnational organized immigration crimes. In order to improve security and strengthen state legitimacy the Federal Government of Somalia is aiming at strengthen
ing the capacity of the Immigration and Naturalisation Directorate IND in line with the National Development Plan. The project will focus on developing the institutional capacity of IND especially its HR Department in order to strengthen the legitimacy of 
the Federal Government of Somalia in the field of immigration and border management. The project will utilize diaspora and international experts in developing capacity and strengthen IND?s infrastructural capabilities to deliver quality public services.   
The project will be implemented by the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) during a period of 14 months in 2020 - 2021. Finland supports the project with 1 000 000 euros.

title: Strengthening food security, agriculture and livelihoods in Somaliland
description: We will work with farmers across four communities in Somaliland to protect their land against extreme weather, making it suitable to cultivate a sustainable source of food to feed their families and earn an income, directly benefitting 1,620 people. In order to strengthen resilience, 230 small-scale farmers will gain improved access to water sources, including shallow wells and water pumps, and 40 farmers will be trained in local coping mechanisms. This project will also work in collaboration with the government to strengthen long term support for local farmers.

title: SF Alert CV19 091 - Somalia Covid-19

title: Empowering communities to challenge FGM and prevent COVID-19 in Gabiley
description:
This project aims to replicate the successful approaches of FGM prevention projects previously supported by the Adelman Foundation, and combine COVID-19 prevention messaging to ensure the wide range of community representatives involved in challenging FGM are also able to share lifesaving information on COVID-19.

The COVID-19 prevention activities will reach 16,000 households, directly benefitting approximately 96,000 people. By supporting Somaliland’s efforts to reduce the spread and impact of COVID-19, we hope to strengthen our FGM programme. The FGM component of this project will directly benefit 1,208 people living in rural communities of Gabiley District, indirectly benefitting tens of thousands more through the sharing of information and influencing up to 20,000 people through media programmes.

title: Supporting Pastoralism and Agriculture in Recent and Protracted Crises (SPARC)
description: The Supporting Pastoralism & Agriculture in Recurrent & Protracted Crises (SPARC) programme will help poor and vulnerable people better cope with crises and increase their resilience to recurring shocks and protracted crisis and conflict by addressing evidence gaps on the effectiveness of different programmes and policies supporting, rebuilding, and increasing the resilience of agricultural livelihoods. As a result of the programme more people will have access to quality agricultural support during protracted and recurrent crisis.

title: Supporting Pastoralism and Agriculture in Recurrent and Protracted Crises (SPARC)
description: Supporting Pastoralism and Agriculture in Recurrent and Protracted Crisis (SPARC) is a six-year (2020-2026) £19.9 million research initiative funded by the UK’s Foreign Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO). It addresses knowledge gaps and generates evidence to help people cope with crises and meet their basic needs in the Horn of Africa, Sahel, and the Middle East. There are many drivers of crisis and poverty in this region. They include climate change, which has increasing impact on fragile, natural resource-based livelihoods. The target group for this programme are poor men and women, primarily in pastoralist areas of the Sahel and East Africa, who can benefit from improved agricultural support. SPARC’s work is intended to inform FCDO’s and other development agencies’ programmes to strengthen the resilience of agricultural and pastoralist livelihoods, in the context of climate change. SPARC will: 1) Undertake new research that builds the evidence base where there are clear gaps on how to effectively deliver programmes and adapt policies. 2) Develop and support innovation, including through the use of technology, in FCDO and partner programmes, and in response to emerging agendas. 3) Targeted technical support to  country offices and programmes in the design, delivery and evaluation of existing programmes. 4) Develop and share lessons by curating knowledge, convening debates and undertaking broader communications and engagement initiatives to inform both the development of future policies and programmes, and technical support, ensuring that the research remains operationally relevant. 5) Research uptake and dissemination: to ensure that new analysis and tailored research is highly accessible to policy- and decision-makers, so that they can benefit from the programme’s innovation and learning and apply it to their work. The programme will engage closely with FCDO country offices to ensure that FCDO country programmes and policies build on the evidence generated from the research. The programme helps deliver the UK Humanitarian Reform Policy and World Humanitarian Summit commitments.

implementing: Payment to Partner (International Livestock Research Institute)

title: Support for the Federal Government of Somalia to strengthen domestic revenue generation and macroeconomic management
description: The project is working with the Federal Government of Somalia to develop and improve customs practices according to international and regional standards, leading to growth in available domestic revenues for Somalia and corresponding growth in both government spending and increased trade and investment. Focusing on strengthening customs operations and revenue collection of the Federal Government of Somalia including a modernization of customs regime throughout the country, CowaterSogema, alongside local and regional partners, is working closely with the Revenue Department at the Ministry of Finance, as well as the customs entities at Mogadishu port and airport. The project’s primary result areas are providing support in customs policy and legislative and regulatory reform, working with the customs administration to introduce reforms and improve enforcement mechanisms at major ports and airports, and strengthening the organisational capacity of the customs administration. The project is building capacity in customs enforcement and compliance which includes risk management, anti-smuggling, post-clearance audit and intelligence; investigation and valuation and declaration. A Strategic Plan for Compliance and Enforcement is being developed. Throughout the project, the team is supporting the development and implementation of an integrated change management and communications strategy both internally and externally to help improve the perception of customs reform. Capacity building is being implemented through classroom-based and on-the-job training and mentorship. Identifying and conceptualising the new reports, financial statements, and financial tables, as per ECOWAS guidelines and RBM best practices; Establishing a set of criteria used to compare the different systems implementation options; Preparing the specifications document and the analysis framework; Analysing the proposed software against the analysis framework.

title: Improving living conditions in urban areas and improving the integration of returnees (MPF), Phase II
description: Im Rahmen des Vorhabens soll die städtische Infrastruktur in den Städten Mogadischu, Baidoa und Kismayo in Südzentral-Somalia verbessert und so ein Beitrag zur Verbesserung der Lebensbedingungen der Bevölkerung, dort angesiedelter Binnenflüchtlinge sowie der aus Dadaab zurückkehrenden Flüchtlinge geleistet werden. Darüber hinaus trägt das Projekt zur Stabilisierung der fragilen Sicherheitslage in den Projektstädten Südzentral-Somalias bei und fördert so die Friedenskonsolidierung vor Ort, wie im Marshallplan mit Afrika, "Afrika und Europa - Neue Partnerschaft für Entwicklung, Frieden und Zukunft" gefordert. Der Ansatz zielt auf die Verbesserung sozialer und produktiver Infrastruktur und ist multisektoral, sodass Maßnahmen in den Bereichen Transport, Wasser- und Sanitärversorgung, Müllentsorgung, Bildung und Gesundheit möglich sind. In Mogadischu wurden bereits Maßnahmen im Bereich kommunale Infrastruktur identifiziert, für die Städte Kismayo und Baidoa wurden Vorstudien erstellt. Die einzelnen Maßnahmen werden im Rahmen der Umsetzung festgelegt. Zur Planung und Umsetzung der o.g. Maßnahmen werden die Strukturen des Multi Partner Fund der Weltbank (MPF) genutzt, der zur Umsetzung der FZ-Mittel ein gesondertes Finanzierungsfenster für städtische Infrastruktur einrichtet. Zur Förderung des von der Gebergemeinschaft angestrebten "State-Building" werden somalische Regierungsstrukturen soweit wie möglich in die Planung, Gestaltung und Umsetzung der Maßnahmen eingebunden. Auch die direkte Anbindung an den nationalen Entwicklungsplan ist damit sichergestellt.

description: Das Projekt wird zur Ernährungssicherheit und zu einer verbesserten Adoptionsfähigkeit und Widerstandsfähigkeit der Zielgemeinden gegenüber dem Klimawandel beitragen.

title: Beschäftigungsförderung für IDPs, Rückkehrer und aufnehmende Gemeinden durch arbeitsintensive Infrastrukturmaßnahmen
description: During the project period improved access to basic social services and employment shall be provided for internally displaced people (IDP), returning refugees and host communities. The main focus is to rehabilitate productive infrastructre like roads, drainage and lightening. Through improved productive infrastructure in and to communities of IDPs, returning refugees and host communities, the project contributes to improvement of local living conditions. The labor intensive implementation provides short-term employment for IDPs, returning refugees and locals and helps to increase the economic status. The project contributes to stabilization of the fragile security situation in the region and therefore fulfills the second pillar "Peace, Security and Stabilization" of the "Marshallplan with Africa" by the german BMZ.

title: Improving living conditions in urban areas and improving the integration of returnees (MPF), Phase III
description: Im Rahmen des Vorhabens soll die städtische Infrastruktur in Städten in Südzentral-Somalia (Mogadischu, Baidoa und Kismayo) sowie Puntland (Garowe) verbessert werden. Das Projekt zielt darauf ab, einen Beitrag zur Verbesserung der Lebensbedingungen der Bevölkerung und dort angesiedelter Binnenflüchtlinge sowie zurückkehrender Flüchtlinge zu leisten. Darüber hinaus trägt das Projekt zur Stabilisierung der fragilen Sicherheitslage in den Projektstädten bei und fördert so die Friedenskonsolidierung vor Ort. Das stimmt mit den Forderungen im Marshallplan mit Afrika "Afrika und Europa - Neue Partnerschaft für Entwicklung, Frieden und Zukunft" überein. Der Ansatz zielt auf die Verbesserung sozialer und produktiver Infrastruktur und ist multisektoral, sodass Maßnahmen in den Bereichen Transport, Wasser- und Sanitärversorgung, Müllentsorgung, Bildung und Gesundheit möglich sind. In Mogadischu wurden bereits Maßnahmen im Bereich kommunale Infrastruktur identifiziert, für die Städte Kismayo, Baidoa und Garowe wurden Vorstudien erstellt. Die einzelnen Maßnahmen werden im Rahmen der Umsetzung festgelegt. Zur Planung und Umsetzung der o.g. Maßnahmen werden die Strukturen des Multi Partner Fund der Weltbank (MPF) genutzt, der zur Umsetzung der FZ-Mittel ein gesondertes Finanzierungsfenster für städtische Infrastruktur einrichtet. Zur Förderung des von der Gebergemeinschaft angestrebten "State-Building" werden somalische Regierungsstrukturen soweit wie möglich in die Planung, Gestaltung und Umsetzung der Maßnahmen eingebunden. Auch die direkte Anbindung an den nationalen Entwicklungsplan ist damit sichergestellt.

title: Beschäftigungsbefähigung durch Stärkung beruflicher Qualifikation
description: Im Rahmen des Vorhabens soll der Zugang von Jugendlichen und jungen Menschen in drei ausgewählten Städten in den südlichen und zentralen Mitgliedsstaaten zu qualitativ hochwertiger Berufsbildung verbessert werden. Damit wird ein Beitrag zur Verringerung der Jugendarbeitslosigkeit und zur lokalen Wirtschaftsentwicklung geleistet. Hierfür werden schrittweise in Galkayo, Jowhar und Baidoa integrierte Gewerbeschulzentren aus- und neugebaut und ausgestattet. Das Konzept der integrierten Gewerbeschule zeichnet sich zum einen durch einen an klaren Qualitäts- und Prüfungskriterien ausgerichteten, praxisorientierten Unterricht aus. Zum anderen bieten die Gewerbeschulen verschiedene Dienstleistungen im Bereich Weiterbildung und Unternehmensförderung für die lokale Wirtschaft an. Das Vorhaben unterstützt die Gewerbeschulzentren dabei, ein breites Dienstleistungsangebot zu entwickeln, dadurch Einnahmen zu generieren und sich mit einem nachhaltigen Finanzierungsmechanismus langfristig selbst unterhalten zu können. Durch die Verankerung in die lokalen Gemeinden und den Einbezug benachteiligter und vulnerabler Jugendliche verschiedener Clans sowie von Binnenvertriebenen sollen die Gewerbeschulen als friedensstiftende Begegnungsorte und Entwicklungspole der lokalen Wirtschaft wirken.
