title: CO-Drought & Sever Water Shortages Respo
description:
2020 was one of the hardest years for Somalia in decades. Flooding, COVID-19 and recurring locust invasions heavily impacted on theeconomy and livelihoods of people. The government implemented measures to contain COVID-19, including the closure of schools, reduction of movement and other economic activities. The coastal areas of Puntland and Somaliland were also hit by cyclone Gati in November 2020, resulting in a sharp increase in humanitarian needs which many organizations - including Oxfam Somalia - responded to. While the performance of the 2020 Gu rain was near normal, the Deyr rain of 2020 has been categorized a complete failure due to the La Nina conditions. These developments triggered severe water shortages in many regions and districts in Somalia. Since October 2020, regional administrations, communities and other humanitarian agencies have been sending alerts about looming drought conditions in many parts of Somalia.Oxfam’s feedback hotline continues to receive a high number of calls from people requesting immediate water interventions. These callers are mainly from the Sool, Sanaag and Togdheer regions. UNOCHA assessment findings indicate that over 50% of the communities in the assessed locations reported displacement of people due to water shortages, 85% raised major concerns on watershortages, and 14 out of 40 villages reported an increase in diarrheal cases. The price of water has already more than doubled. According to Oxfam’s own market assessment, one barrel of water is currently being sold at an average of USD 4.5 per barrel, with some villages reporting over USD 7 per barrel. This is forcing the most vulnerable households to travel long distances to fetch water and/or opt for poor water quality and risk their lives. The most affected communities include IDPs and low-income host communities. Women and girls are at risk of protection-related risks as they travel in search of water.
Regarding COVID-19, over 4,784 cases with over 130 fatalities were registered by the WHO in Somalia since the start of the pandemic, with many cases left undetected due to asymptomatic infections, low testing capacity and the stigmatisation of COVID-19 cases among the population. The second wave of the pandemic seems to have also hit the country as the number of cases started to increase in the last few months. The government of Somaliahas eased most of the restrictions in August 2020 and most of the public services have resumed. This increases the risk of vulnerability to COVID-19 and the shortages of water in many areas further restrict the communities' ability to frequently wash their hands with soap. This might create a favourable environment for COVID-19 to spread.
The Ministry of Water Development in Somaliland shareda request with all humanitarian agencies, indicating that over 196,848 people are in need of urgent water interventions and that many others also require quick rehabilitations of their water sources. Over 88% of the people in need are from the Sool, Sanaag, and Togdheer regions of Eastern Somaliland. In October 2020, Oxfam using the ECHO crisis modifier budget reached the most vulnerable 1,800 HH (10,800 people) in Sool, Sanaag, and Togdheer for 30 days with WASH interventions. Since then, we have continued to advocate for urgent interventions by sharing summary reports with the Somalia WASH cluster and presentations of the situation with cluster members. Utilising other existing resources, we are also working with the Ministry of Water Resources to rehabilitate boreholes that were identified as strategic wells by the government.

title: CO-localization influencing
description:
AIM
• localization influencing, especially focused on womens rights organisations.
• Our work with Nexus and Somali NGO Consortium it has become clear that there are clear gaps and opportunities to engage with WROs on localization and humanitarian issues
• WROs’ leadership and involvement in the sector will be strengthened, which at the moment is very low, including in our programmes

ACTIVITIES
• Series of workshops bringing together WROs across Somalia/Somaliland to hear their perspectives and involvement in the humanitarian sector and on localization
• Short policy brief on WROs involvement in the humanitarian sector (funding, partnerships, decision-making)
• Showcasing WROs willing and with capacity to engage more in the humanitarian sector: to other NGOs, UN, donors
• Virtualtraining for WROs to learn from each other and others on the localization agenda; humanitarian sector decision-making and funding

title: Innovative Fishery Development
description:
The first component is aimed at capacity building. At least 40 beneficiaries (at least 30% female) including fishermen and women, fishmongers will undergo a maximum of six months theoretical and practical training. Youth fishermen and women will be trained on safety at sea, fishing gear mending and repairs, safe fishing methods and fish preservation, cooperatives establishment and fish quality assurance. Fishmongers, who will mostly be women, will be trained in various topics including fish handling and preservation, fishprocessing, personal hygiene, value addition (processing, grading, and packaging) and small business management. Entrepreneurship will be an integral part of the courses in order to leverage the entrepreneurship capacity
The second component is aimed at supporting the establishment/ strengthening of fishery organizations. The target beneficiaries will be organized in Self Help Groups (SHGs). The SHG is a rights-based approach which views poverty as the denial of rights and poverty alleviation as a process of reclaiming one’s rights. Given the multi-dimensional nature of poverty, the SHG Approach puts equal emphasis on the goals of economic, social andpolitical empowerment . Therefore, the established/strengthened SHGs will have the potential to empower small-scale fishers againstsome of the environmental and socioeconomic shocks such as fish catch shortfalls and revenues, sickness and death in their families, natural disasters and hunger. The 30 young fishermen will be organized intoat least 5 SHGs and will be trained/ oriented on the operations of the SHGs
The third component will support the distribution of fishing kits/gear to the SHGs including women fishmongers.Midway through the training, the project beneficiaries will be provided with fishing gears in their SGHs. Such gear may include boats and other necessary tools. On the other hand, women fishmongers, will have business start-up kits including refrigerators and basic fish processing tools. The fishing kits/ gear will be owned and managed jointly in the SHGs.
The fourth component will focus on learning and knowledge management through value chain research. In order to ensure systematic market mapping in the fishing sector, understand actors, market share, capacity gaps, and other relevant value chain information, the project will undertake a robust research on fish value chain. The research will aim to bring out suitable models to link small holders to input and output markets and improve the benefits that fishermen and women and other resource-poor value chain actors derive from the chain. Knowledge generated from the research will be disseminated to different relevant stakeholders in the sector. It will also act as a building block for future scaling efforts of the project. As Oxfam and the partner have both long-term livelihood strategies, the research finding would beused for future programing.

title: Strengthening  Capacity of Nexus Members
description:
Somalia, a fragile State that is emerging from decades of civil war, is currently experiencing an unprecedented situation mainly caused by climate change, Covid-19 and locust infestation, which exacerbated the long-term existed challenges within the country including widespread vulnerability and marginalization, insecurity and government with poor institutional capacity to deliver and advocate for basic humanitarian needs of local communities, combination of the above mentioned challenges contributed to negative socio-economic impact on Somali communities and resulted in the displacement of affected populations (mainly rural) and formation of IDP sites alongside main towns.
Other challenges encountered by Somalia and Somaliland communities include lack of coping capacity to climate change and widespread dependency created by Humanitarian Aid due to the absence of government’s role that affects the livelihood of entire communities rather than building their long-term resilience. It's evident that the Humanitarian Aid Dependency has largely affected the productivity of the Somali population. However, there's need to exhaust to what extent these will be addressed by our research questions for the Participatory Action Research (PAR) on Aid Humanitarian Aid dependency.
In 2019, nine Somali NGOs founded the Nexus platform that aims to shape the future in Somalia and Somaliland, by creating an enabling environment for Somali NGOs to have a leading role in the humanitarian system that puts the agency and self-reliance of communities at the center, through delivering a combination of Humanitarian Aid, Development, and Peace interventions. The Nexus coalition is led by nine Somali NGOs – African Development Solutions (ADESO), Centre for Peace and Democracy (CPD), Gargaar Relief and Development Organization (GREDO), Horn of Africa Voluntary Youth Committee (HAVOYOCO), KAALO, Save Somali Women and Children (SSWC), Social-Life and Agriculture Development Organisation (SADO), Taakulo Somaliland Community (TASCO), and WASDA. Two INGOs – Oxfam and Save the Children International were invited to join as international partners to support with critical investments.
So far the platform developed and applied its strategy andtheory of change whilst Humanitarian actions are the platform’s immediate priority in its current scope of work, Somalia Nexus consortium aims to focus interventions that are in line with its pillars, including Community-driven and working across the Triple Nexusof Development, Humanitarian Aid, Peace-building and conflict-resolution, as well as strengthening the capacity of Somali Civil Society <(>&<)> Government institutions. In addition, special considerations will be given concerning practicality and implementation methodology including presence, scaleof the need, duration and coordination with other stakeholders.
The day-to-day activities of theplatform are performed by the Secretariat supported by the Steering committee who are also responsible for resource mobilization, organizing coordination meetings, fund management and drafting policies and guidelines
In 2021, the Nexus platform aims to implement efforts to support its members and government institutions in both Somalia and Somaliland, through development of Community-driven Development manuals, conducting Participatory Action Research that finds durable solutions on climate related challenges in both pastoral and agro-pastoral communities, conducting PAR that aims to address the level and scope of dependency created by Unconditional Cash disbursement to local rural communities as well as supporting Somalia and Somaliland governments to develop standardized Cash Transfer model with clear guidelines.
Social inclusion, protection and Covid-19 protocols will be maintained and mainstreamed in project interventions.

title: CO-WASH Innovation Fund
description:
COVID19 disease has been identified in China and later declared as a global pandemic by WHO on March 11, 2020. In Somalia and Somaliland, the first case of the disease was reported in March 2020, and since then, the government authorities implemented measures including movement restrictions, banning all community gathering, closing schools and other religious facilities. Somalia has over three million internally displaced communities (OCHA, Somalia) and over 79% of Somalis are living either below or near the internationalpoverty line (NDP-9, Somalia). The majority of IDPs live in overcrowded settlements with weakened infrastructure, insufficient access to WASH facilities and inaccessible health services. Since later last year, the locust manifestation and floods destroyed majority posture and farmland deteriorating the already weakened communities.
Somalia is one of the worst prepared countries in the world to contain the disease. WHO recommends the use of personal protective equipment, frequent handwashing and social distance to contain COVID19. Oxfam Somalia works with communities to promote these critical measures and raise awareness of communities on COVID19. Thissupport requires a close engagement with communities and health volunteers. However, since the first COVID19 case was declared in Somalia, we have limited our community contact and tried to see possible options to provide Real-time support to our communities. This included using a mobile-based application, Well Beyond, to provide COVID19 prevention and containment training. This trail was found to be effective and efficient. We are now proposing the scale up the same approach to expand to include other training including hygiene promotions, WASHCO training, WASH <(>&<)> Protection related training.
COVID19 has changed our traditional ways of living, working and our regular ways of implementing programs. For ownership and sustainability, it is critical to ensure communities' involvement in program design and implementation. In COVID19 environment, this can only be possible by using technologies to deliver training, information and collect feedback.
We wish to deploy critically needed information into the Oxfam Somalia regions of work through the Well Beyond App. This life-saving mobile technology sends interactive COVID-19 and Sanitation and Hygiene training material tothe community based health voluneteers. The technology will fill knowledge gap between COVID-19 recommendations and the tools and knowledge available in the remote, rural places. It serve by providing vital training material, guidance on handwashing stations, surface hygiene, sanitation and real-time chat support, and other tools to help communities prevent the spread of COVID-19. At the sametime, Oxfam Somalia will be able to track training completions and collect data on the solution’s success. This will allow the Oxfam field team to continuously interact with our beneficiaries and community health volunteers.

The UN Economic Commission for Africaprojected more than hundreds of thousands of Africans could lose their lives due to COVID-19. The Somali government, in alignment with the WHO, emphasizes that basic, preventative measures by individuals and communities remain the most powerful tool to prevent the spread of COVID-19, but delivering this critical information has been a challenge, as the movement within countries is very limited, and social distancing guidelines prohibit large group trainings in person. The Well Beyond App will allow us to provide this crucial guidance to our CHVs and support to our communities, even though we aren’t physically able to be there.

title: CO-Rapid Assessment CFM
description:
Oxfam’s commitment is to actively centre the voice and experience of people and community in all our work and consider power, privilege and equity in the design of community-based feedback and complaints mechanisms CBFCMS, and to respect the knowledge, wisdom andperspective of others, as there is always scope for Oxfam to grow and learn as an organisation working with communities.
Functionalfeedback and complaints mechanisms that are accessible and safe to use are a demonstration of our organization-wide accountability commitment, to be truly accountable to the people and communities we work with and those affected by our programmes, by ensuring that they understand what is appropriate and inappropriate conduct of our staff and partners, getting their feedback about our programmes and/or complaints about conduct of our staff, agents or partners  and taking appropriate action to address these concerns. Accountability is “the process of using power responsibly, taking account of, and being held accountable by different stakeholders, and primarily those who are affected by the exercise of such power” . It is the right to be heard, and the duty to respond.

However, anecdotal information indicates that where CBFCMs initiatives and experiences exist in Oxfam, many are still disjointed, some are uncoordinated, and largely undocumented. In many places, they are non-existent, or if they are, not all of them are fully functional. The design of Oxfam’s CBFCMs by Affiliates, Country Offices and in part Partners has not always ensured community involvement, in most cases resulting in not fit for purpose mechanisms. Also different affiliates still approach the issue of CBFCMs differently with different emphasis, approaches, tools and resources, therefore lacking a standardised coordinated approach.

Although Oxfam prides itself for encouraging communities we work with to speak out and report PSEA and child protection concerns and incidents concerning them,recent reports in some countries like DRC, Ethiopia, and Uganda not only attests to the limited awareness at community level on SEAand child protection risks and reporting mechanisms, but has also led to an increase in attention to ensure that SEA and child abuse and exploitation by humanitarian and development organisations like Oxfam are addressed through investment in preventive approaches but also responding to reports of abuse and exploitation when these incidents are reported.
Oxfam has two responsibilities for accountability in the programmes it manages, holding a responsibility for mutual accountability with its partners (as do the partners) and also holding a shared or joint accountability (with its partners) to the communities affected by its programmes. There is lack of knowledge how the
In addition to some of the above challenges, COVID-19 has added additional challenges to how effective current CBFCMs are, placing additional barriers to reporting that are currently not fully understood or risks mitigated.
OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT:
1. Map out existing CBCM’s initiatives in select field/project locations, and document best practices and lessons learnt in implementing CBFCMs across the Oxfam confederation
2. Undertake a rapid assessment of the existing CBFCMs in Oxfam terms of effectiveness, experiences and lessons plus existing gaps.

title: Supporting on Borehole Drill  in Somalia
description:
The eastern regions in Somaliland and especially Saanag and Sool regions continue to suffer from recurrent drought. This situation has increased the vulnerability of the communities as they have lost most of their livestock which was their main source oflivelihood. The situation is exacerbated by the fact that the two regions also continue to experience occasional inter clan fighting which isoften triggered by competition for available pasture and water resources. Drilling of the a boreholes will not only contribute to providing important water sources that can support the water needs of the communities during drought and harsh climatic conditions, but also contribute to reducing risk factors leading to conflict. It will offer an opportunity to the benefiting communities to have a chance for better access to potable water, reduce the incidents water related diseases and increase access for water for practicing frequent handwashing to prevent COVID-19.
Objectives;
• Provide sustainable water source for 5000 people and over 10,000 livestockheads in Sanaag Region.
Groundwater Feasibility Study:
A groundwater feasibility study will be conducted in three selected villagesof Sanaag region. the study will follow three approach method,
1. Remote Sensing: Desk review using latest satellite imageries to selected best possible locations. This phase will focus on finding regional fractures carrying water from highland of Ethiopia to thelowland of Sanaag regions and from Sanaag mountains to low land areas.
2. Geophysical Study: ground truthing work will be conducting using latest start of art geophysical technology at least three locations with spacing of 1000 -1500m. This location are those selected in first phase of the study work. Government and community engagement will be conducted to understand the local geology, possible impact of drilling on environment and stability of the communities.
Drilling of the borehole
Based on the groundwater feasibility study, the drilling work will be advertised through the local media. In order to avoid failures resulted from improper use of drilling equipment and selection of drilling method, the contractor will receive full copy of the study report and will be given a briefing on the drilling technology and technique recommended by the study team. Then, a payment by result approach will be used to contract drilling companies i.e. Oxfam/Taakulo will only pay if the borehole has water with discharge of above 2liter per second. Failureto get a contractor willing to commence drilling with such conduction, further meeting will be help between Oxfam and Taakulo to discuss best possible approach to increase value for money.
Supervision and Monitoring:
In drilling works supervision and monitoring progress is critical step. Oxfam/Taakulo will have a site supervisor equipped with necessary materials for supervision including TDS Sensor to record water quality at each 1 meter, mud funnel to record the drilling mud viscosity and deeper to follow the depth of the drilling. The supervisor will provide daily update to both Oxfam/Taakulo team and will ensure all decision that affect drilling performance is consulted and agreed before action. TDS level will be recorded in monitoring tool provided and the result will be used for deciding the borehole casing arrangement. All materials that will be used for drilling will be inspected by the drilling supervisor and approve. In case a specialized chemical will be used for the drilling; the supervisor will request for all safety related certificate prior use of such chemicals.
Post Drilling Construction:
This action will be decided right after the drilling is completed. Provision of submersible pump with cable and riser pipes, and construction of generator house, water distribution system for both animal and human and storage facilities will be included under this phase. Other grants, including ECHO 2021 and/or other internal grants will be used to finance this critical activity. Incase the borehole salinity is above an acceptable regional level i.e. 2500ppm, provision of desalination unit will be considered.

title: CO-Drought Effected People  Response (RR
description:
In response to the current water and food shortages caused by the ‘triple threat’ of
drought, locust and COVID-19 in Eastern Somaliland, Oxfam and local partner Taakulo
will support 43,800 rural IDPs and host communities (pastoralists) with integrated WASH
and Food Security interventions in the Sool, Sanaag and Togdheer regions.
The WASH component will reach over 43,800 people with clean drinking water and an improved and safe access to rehabilitated water sources. Existing water market structures will be sustainably strengthened through Cash for Water interventions and water prices prevented from rising by solarizing water sources and providing operators with the means to maintain existing desalination units.
1,036 households ( 6,216 women, men, boys and girls) will be supported through the food security and livelihoods assistance component. The Sida RRM will contribute to addressing the immediate food needs of the people affected by drought and the socioeconomic impact of COVID-19. Oxfam and Taakulo will respond through cash assistance that allows households to meet their basic food needs. Community and government engagement will be at the centre of the response and close engagement is ensured during the project design and implementation stages as this will increase ownership and social accountability, and ensure sustainability after our intervention ends.

title: Maailmanpankin yhteisrahoitusohjelma Somaliassa
description:
World Bank's Multi-Partner Fund (MPF) supports Somalia's stabilization and peacebuilding by strengthening Somalia's governance and the management of the state's revenues (including taxation) as well as by reviving the country's economy and the private sect
or to allow increased state revenues through taxation and to provide resources for extended and improved public services. In the project level the funded projects focus around four thematic priority areas which include government's key functions; productiv
e sectors and employment; infrastructure development; as well as management of natural resources and resilience. For example the Fund can support the payment of Somalia's government officials' salaries and improve the public financial management systems; b
oost the productivity and the value chains of potential productive sectors and improve youth employment (allowing also greater tax revenues); improve the infrastructure and therefroe improve the productivity among else in the energy sector; and strengthen 
the resilience of selected groups and professions such as cattle herders/pastoralists.The Fund also supports one of Finland's priority sectors the Health sector by strengthening health governance's salary payment and financial management systems as well as
 by supporting the governance capacity in the sector.The Fund operates in close partnership with the Federal Government of Somalia as well as with the donors and international agencies through the New Deal framework and through its aid infrastructure Somal
ia Development and Reconstruction Facility (SDRF) offering peace and statebuilding support to the Somali transition process. Finland together with other international partners has committed itself to work increasingly through the New Deal structures.Finlan
d supports the MPF over the period of 2016-2019 with 4MEUR which is disbursed as follows: 2016: 2MEUR 2018: 1MEUR 2019: 1MEUR.

title: Hiil hooyo - aitiysterveyden edistamishanke
description:
Hiil hooyo is a multi-actor joint project addressing maternal healthcare in Somaliland and Puntland. The key development problem is high maternal mortality having multiple negative effects. Maternal mortality rate in the project areas is one of the highest
 in the world. The project seeks to enhance women's right and the right of persons with disabilities to maternal healthcare. The project started in 2017 with a pilot phase and the new phase aims to make the results sustainable.The main outcomes are:1. Skil
ls and motivation of healthcare workers improved2. Number of mothers and children attending MCHs increased3. Attendance and accessibility of persons with disabilities to MCHs increased4. Partner universities able to conduct independently e-learning program
 in maternal healthcare and students benefitted from the developed materialThe main outputs and activities include:- 240 healthcare workers passed in-service training on maternal healthcare; 4 trainings- 10 000 persons reached by awareness raising programs
; village meetings school classes media campaigns home visits fathers clubs- 460 persons trained on the rights of persons with disabilities; training of trainers workshops- 120 university students passed e-learning program in maternal healthcare teachers t
rained and partner universities networking; e-course for students on-line training for teachers joint meetingsThe project is implemented in 10 districts in 3 areas. For the implementation the FSN has 6 NGO partners of which 3 its member organizations in Fi
nland and 5 university partners of which 2 (Diak and Xamk) in Finland. In addition the Disability Partnership Finland (DPF) offers expertize for disability issues. The innovative cooperative model enforces the civil society and enhances stability.The benef
iciaries of the project include healthcare workers pregnant and breastfeeding mothers with their families persons with disabilities university lecturers and students students in secondary schools the NGO partners and indirectly communities in general in th
e project areas with an estimated population of 15 million.

title: HALO/Humanitaarinen miinatoiminta Somaliassa
description:
HALOs project will support and strengthen Somalias security stability and development through humanitarian mine action and stockpile destruction. HALOs project seeks to 1) contribute to the human security and reduce civilian accidents and casualties by lim
iting the impact and proliferation of explosive items 2) contribute to the peace dividend and assist fragile communities in their own efforts to reinstate a working and stable society and 3) reduce poverty and hunger by removing blockage to high priority i
nfrastructure water access and roads. The project takes place in two phases: First completing the manual clearance of Somaliland at which point mine action in Somaliland will become completely owned funded and implemented by national authorities with suffi
cient capacity to tackle any residual tasking. Finland has supported this project since 2003. Second HALO will seek and destroy community held or abandoned stockpiles of ammunition held outside of state control across their area of operations in Southern S
omalia. The primary beneficiaries of the project are local populations in areas where HALO will conduct mine clearance and stockpile destruction. Finland will support HALOs project in Somalia during 2017-2020 with one million euros.

title: UNFPA Somalia Wellbeing of Women and Girls
description:
Support to the UN Population Fund's (UNFPA) country programme continues Finland's strong contribution for the development of Somalia's reproductive maternal and child health care services. UNFPA has been among the three UN agencies that have been involved 
in the UN Joint Nutrition and Health Programme in Somalia (JHNP) which focused on the development of maternal and child health services. Finland supported the implementation of the programme for 15.5MEUR between 2014-2016. JHNP has provided services for an
 area covering half of Somalia's population. It has reached good results having significantly contributed to the reduction of maternal and infant mortality. Through JHNP UNFPA has supported the provision of maternal sexual and reproductive health services 
as well as contributed to improving their quality. UNFPA has supported the running of 135 maternal clinics; the training of midwifes in 15 midwiferies throughout Somalia; the provision of training on reproductive health for over 600 health care professiona
ls; as well as the provision of technical assistance to the ministries of health to support their capacity building including their work on health sector strategic development. As JHNP is coming to an end in early-2017 UNFPA continues the work to develop t
he reproductive maternal and child health care in Somalia according to its mandate.UNFPA country strategy for Somalia for 2011-2016 has been extended for one year to cover also 2017. Its overall objective is to improve the wellbeing of Somali people. The c
ountry strategy aims to achieve this through reducing maternal mortality and through supporting the realization of reproductive rights and services. In addition the strategy supports gender equality and combats gender-based violence as well as strengthens 
the Somali statistical systems and promotes evidence-based planning and policy design.Three particular priority areas have been identified for 2017:1.Increased provision of comprehensive sexual and reproductive health services (around 50% of the annual bud
get for 2017)2.Promotion of gender equality and prevention of gender-based violence (around 25% of the 2017 budget)3.Strengthened national capacity on use of quality disaggregated data for evidence-based planning and policy design on population and develop
ment issues (around 25% of the 2017 budget)Finland supports the implementation of the UNFPA Somalia country strategy for 2011-2017 for 2 million euros.

title: Somaliland Health Sector Support (MIDA Finnsom IV)
description:
IOM MIDA Finnsom IV project focuses on contributing to improved health outcomes in Somaliland and particularly its remote regions. To achieve this the project supports the capacity of public sector institutions to provide quality health services. Three out
puts have been defined:1.) Local health professionals have skills/capacity to deliver quality health services2.) Local health training institutions have improved competence and ability to train local health professionals 3.) Ministry of Health has increase
d capacity to steer manage and coordinate the health sector The Somali diaspora experts particularly the Finnish Somali diaspora experts are the actors in the capacity building efforts. They train the local health professionals and participate in developin
g strategies plans standards and curricula for health sector. Particular attention is given to women's and child health. In the long term the project is expected to contribute to better health outcomes for Somaliland population and especially the health ou
tcomes for women and children.The first Finnish funded MIDA project was initiated already in 2008. The project has been evaluated twice and the findings suggest that the project has significantly strengthened public health institutions ability to provide q
uality services in Somaliland. The findings and recommendations of evaluations have been duly notified in the planning of the Finnsom IV phase: For example the project now focuses on the more remote regions in Somaliland where service provision is poorer t
han in the capital Hargeisa. Similarly following the recommendations the length of the assignments of diaspora experts has been increased for Phase IV.To support the implementation of the project the National Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) also imp
lements tailored trainings for the Ministry of Health.The duration of the Phase IV is four years from March 2017 until February 2021. The budget for the project is 4 300 000 Euros. Somalia is considered an LDC country.

title: Somalia Humanitarian and Resilience Program (SHARP) Building Resilience Communities in Somalia II (BRCIS II): A nutrition sensitive resilience building programme
description: To support and accompany vulnerable Somali communities and systems on their path to restoring and strengthening their resilience to shocks and stresses within the framework of the development goals stated in National Development Plan and UK Humanitarian Reform Policy. BRCiS is designed in such a way that adaptive programming contributes to enhanced learning and coordination for all stakeholders, providing building blocks for long-term resilient development. Outputs Actively contribute to shaping collective approaches to achieving sustainable outcomes in resilience in Somalia, through mainstreaming adaptive management and scalable innovations Protect vulnerable populations from the impact of shocks and stresses through safety nets and actual early action Promote market integrated, shock-proof livelihood opportunities Set the ground for community managed risk reduction through Natural Resource Management, improved governance and early warning systems Enhance access to and utilization of basic services for key vulnerable populations

title: Maternity Clinic and Training Project
description:
Long-running conflict has destroyed the infrastructure of the Somali state and the country has one of the worst health indicators in the world. The high-risk groups are 2.4 million children under age 5 and more than 3 million women of child-bearing age. Ac
cording to WHO the maternal mortality ratio is 732 per 100 000 live births although most of the maternal deaths would be preventable. Rebuilding the health sector is challenged by a shortage of professional staff financial resources and effective governanc
e and NGOs have played a key role in providing with these services. African Cares Maternity Clinic and Training project has since its start in 2012 supported the development of the FinSom maternity clinic together with the local partner VMDSO. Results show
 that the service of the clinic has decreased maternal mortality rate prevalence of tetanus raised awareness about exclusive breast feeding and FGM. The clinic is well-known in Afgoye and surrounding areas and a vital source of quality maternal health care
 for both expectant mothers and the community. Hence the maternal health care services are continued also in the continuation phase of the project.The project at hand seeks to further enhance the capacity and services of the partner and the clinic so that 
eventually maternal health services could be provided without development cooperation funding. This is done by investing in the education and training of the VMDSO staff and health workers and monitoring the long-term impact of the trainings. Simultaneousl
y invaluable information on the key challenges and development needs will be mapped out and used for future trainings.  Also the support of the sexual violence victims will be intensified. It will be expanded to an in-person counselling in addition to the 
telephone support. Open-access seminars and family counselling are likewise continued and further intensified. Seminars about gender equality family planning and gender-based violence work to dismantle unequal social structures through open dialogue. Proje
ct's beneficiaries are women in labour children victims of sexual violence clinics personnel and partner organization VMDSO.

title: Sahansaho  against desertification in Somalia
description:
The key development problem which the project aims to find solutions to is the desertification leading to lack of livelihoods poverty and forced migration. The objective is sustainable use of natural resources and secured livelihood in the project areas. T
he project started in 2012 and it has been planned for 10 years. This continuation project will be its 4th and final phase.The outcomes of 2019-2022 will be:1. Environmental centers developed into regional hubs2. Educational institutions and trainers have 
expertise to provide environmental education3. Resilience of local communities to climate change and drought improved4. Implementation of policies related to natural resource management (NRM)The outputs will be: 1.1. Seedlings of locally successful species
 produced planted distributed and sold per year 1.2. Seed collection stands established and local availability of the seeds of the most important species secured 1.3. Operating models for the environmental centers developed 2.1. Trainers trained and traini
ng material produced 2.2. Training materials and research opportunities provided to universities and environmental education material provided to teachers 3.1. Charcoal and firewood consumption reduced in local communities 3.2. Agroforestry practices and s
oil and water conservation techniques adopted in local communities 4.1.  Network of the environmental actors built and environmental efforts and common initiatives coordinated at all project sites 4.2.  Policy reviews and briefs produced for policy dialogu
e with ministries of environment and implementation of environmental policies startedThe project is implemented at 3 sites in Somalia with the FSN's four partners in Finland and three partners in Somalia. The innovative cooperative model enforces the civil
 society in Somalia and creates new networks  that also promote peace and stability.The beneficiaries are local communities authorities and educational institutions among others.

title: Mustaqbaldoon
description:
The project contributes to the development problem of the vulnerability of the youth which is manifested in youth unemployment and limited access to income causing risky survival strategies such as informal quasi-legal or illegal activities and as a conseq
uence social problems like violence early sexual activity and a range of economic physical and psychological risks.The principal outcomes of the project are 1) Strengthened Civil Society and Local Administration 2) Increased motivation of youth to contribu
te to the society and 3) Increased economic empowerment of youth. The central activities include capacitating the local CSOs and public administration turning the risky survival strategies of youth to healthy ones and 3) training youth to recognize local i
ncome generation opportunities instead of leaving the country.  Developing countries own economies have generated more jobs livelihood opportunities and well-being is the priority area of Finland's development policy the project is aimed at contributing to
. Somalia is ranked as one of the bottom five countries in terms of gender inequality and therefore positive discrimination and affirmative measures will be taken to enhance the participation of young women and girls and to raise awareness about their part
icular needs. The project aims to reduce inequality by emphasizing the rights of all youth as full and equal members of the communities where they live. Project respects climate sustainability too.The project capacitates CSOs and public administration to w
ork with private sector according to multi-stakeholder approach. Helsinki Deaconess Institutes Vamos services is acknowledged in a national level as a unique concept to support vulnerable youth's access to education and employment. The same concept will be
 used together with cooperation partners Y-PEER in Hargeisa and Gedo Development in Gedo. The principal beneficiaries of the project are the youth (15-35 years) who have dropped out from education and employment.

title: Human rights based approach to strengthening community mental health services in Somaliland
description:
The project tackles Somaliland's high burden of mental health problems coupled with a weak mental health care infrastructure which is not able to provide high-quality mental health services from a human rights perspective.The project aims to increase the a
ccess of people to community-based mental health services;promote the adoption of a human rights based approach to mental health in public/private mental health services;and to increase public awareness on mental health issues to decrease the stigma and di
scrimination against people with mental disorders in Somaliland.A special focus is on women/girls and vulnerable groups (SGBV survivorsIDPsdisabled personsprisoners).To support the sustainability of the intervention and to promote the long-term development
 of the mental health care infrastructure in Somalilandthe project will increase the capacity of health care officials to promote mental health from a human rights perspective to coordinate mental health services.The main cross-cutting themes of the projec
t are:health promotionhuman rightsgender equality and good governance.The main activities are: training community mental health workers and social workers to provide community mental health servicesprovision of out-patient treatmentsupporting the capacity 
of the MOH to plan and implement mental health services and policyand raising awareness on mental health.The main beneficiaries of the project are people in Somaliland suffering from mental disorderstheir families and communitiesvulnerable groups in need o
f mental health care civil society and health officials.PSR is well positioned to carry out the project with 30+ years of experience in health development projects also of mental health projects in post-conflict contexts.PSR has long-term project experienc
e in Somalia/Somaliland (2006-) and good local networks.The local partner GAVO is a well-respected local NGO with long-term experience in mental health projects.The Finnish partners FiPSR and Disability Partnership Finland have long-term experience that co
ntributes closely to the project.The project contributes to the FSA project in Jubaland and collaborates with the HDI project in Somaliland

title: Fighting TB in Somalia: public-private partnerships and inclusive communities
description:
The project is founded on PSR's previous projects in Somalia which have developed new strategies to tackle tuberculosis (TB)  especially in community and private sector engagement. A special focus will be placed on women and vulnerable community members: d
isabled persons IDPs and prisoners. Tuberculosis is a central health problem in Somalia. The increase of multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is a global threat  fighting against MDR-TB in Somalia benefits all countries. Another central problem is th
e low treatment coverage rate of about 37% leaving far too many cases untreated further transmitting tuberculosis to others. The impact targets of the project are to: a) tackle multi-drug resistant tuberculosis; and b) increase the tuberculosis case detect
ion rate. The long-term objective of the project is to contribute to the reduction of the tuberculosis burden in Somalia with the following means:1. Increase the access of women and vulnerable groups to TB services (such as disabled personsIDPs and prisone
rs)2. Increase TB referrals from the private sector3. Improve the quality of TB treatment in both the public and private sector4. Improve the quality of TB laboratory work.The central partners of the project are the National Tuberculosis Programmes of Soma
liland and Somalia. PSR has a central role in developing the national tuberculosis diagnostic infrastructure in Somalia. The project will support the National TB Reference Laboratories in Somaliland and South-Central Somalia as well as will treatment of tu
berculosis patients in 3 clinics in Hargeisa and Mogadishu. These clinics will develop innovative community public and private sector engagement models to increase case detection improve treatment quality and to increase public awareness and decrease stigm
a/discrimination. The clinics will also provide HIV services and nutritional support for malnourished patients (with WFP).Together with the local administration the tuberculosis clinics will be transformed into health centers providing specialized tubercul
osis services by the end of 2022 to support integration with basic health services and sustainability after the project has ended.

title: Supporting Inclusive Growth in Somalia (SIGS)
description: SIGS programme is the UK’s flagship economic development programme in Somalia.  Designed as a flexible and adaptive programme it will provide an immediate response to Covid19. It now has a stronger focus on remittances, supporting UK political leadership in this area, and, accelerated support to key Micro, Small and Medium Sized Enterprise (MSME) sectors including domestic food production and marketing.  SIGS will deliver activities to  1.	Develop and diversify businesses in approx. 4 high-value sectors. 2.	Stimulate investment through developing the financial sector and related policy and or regulatory capacity.  3.	Develop the evidence base on inclusive, sustainable, economic development in Somalia.   SIGS will provide an essential policy and influencing resource for UK leadership on HIPC debt relief and or the associated reforms, including on the financial sector and counter terrorist financing.

title: Support to Aid Coordination and Effectiveness in Somalia
description: To improve international aid delivery to Somalia, making it more coordinated, accountable and effective in meeting the needs of the Somali people. UK support will contribute to: a more inclusive, effective and efficient aid architecture; strengthened national ownership and capacity for aid coordination processes and better coherence in the international community’s support for aid coordination and effectiveness. Streamlined processes and increased transparency will support more strategic allocation of resources and improved coordination of effort across the international community. This will also contribute to SDGs 1, 16 and 17 by strengthening institutions to progressively deliver universal access to basic services. The UK played a leading role in the development of Somalia’s aid architecture and has a strong interest in providing an effective platform for coordinated and sustained levels of long-term support for Somalia.

title: Somalia Stability Fund III
description: Somalia Stability Fund III will work to build stability in Somalia. It will do so by deepening understanding of the core underlying causes and drivers of conflict and instability.  It will address them in ways that help widen and deepen the political settlement (agreements between different political actors), at multiple levels, and help build resilience to conflict and violence when these political settlement processes inevitably come under stress.

title: Ramaad - environment relief project in Somalia
description:
Ramaad is a joint project coordinated by the Finnish Somalia Network  (FSN) with its partners addressing the sustainable use and management  of the natural resources in Somalia and desertification that leads to  loss of livelihoods poverty and forced migra
tion. The project started  in 2014 and is planned for 10 years. This is its 4th and final phase.  The long-term objective is sustainable use and management of natural  resources and secured livelihood in the project areas.The outcomes are:1.    3 environme
ntal centers developed into regional hubs with own income2.    Environmental education and awareness increased in project areas3.    Charcoal and firewood consumption reduced by making energy saving  stoves locally available4.    Capacity of administration
s to formulate and implement  environmental policies has increased and implementation of the  policies has startedThe main outputs are:- 30 000 seedlings of locally successful species produced planted  distributed and sold- 90 seed collection stands establ
ished and local availability of the  seeds of the most important species secured- Operating models for the 3 environmental centers developed  partners' capacity to carry out business activities built and  feasibility study for stove fabrication workshops p
repared- Environmental awareness of the local communities and environmental  education in schools increased- 3 stove manufacturing workshops established and 18 craftsmen trained- Environmental efforts and common initiatives coordinated- Implementation of e
nvironmental policies at district and local level startedThe project is implemented in three areas in southern and central  Somalia with the FSN's four partners in Finland and three partner NGOs  in Somalia. The innovative cooperative model enforces the ci
vil  society and enhances stability. The project areas are:1. Guriel and Dhusamareeb Galmudug2. El-Adde Gedo/Jubbaland3. Afmadow Lower Jubba/Jubbaland

title: Somalian sananvapauden journalismin ja julkisen palvelun tukihanke
description:
The continuation phase of Vikes Somalia project supports the Somali national TV channel to develop towards editorially an independent public service broadcaster and assists the national journalist union to become a representative trade union of media worke
rs across Somalia.By providing journalist training and technical support the project seeks to 1) improve the production process and quality of news and other programmes at Somali National Television (SNTV) 2) improve the awareness of media rights and respo
nsibilities and safety of Somali journalists and 3) improve professional skills of women journalists.Project activities include the introduction of regular children?s programme production at SNTV. The project will support the preparation of a journalist co
de of conduct and the drafting of a by-law on public service broadcasting.About 300 journalists across the country will be trained in practical journalism skills media rights and security and professional ethics.The project is based on peer learning. Journ
alists are trained by more experienced Finnish and Somali journalists. Local technicians are trained by experienced Finnish technical experts. Local cameramen and video editors are trained by experienced visiting multimedia professionals from Finland.Main 
cooperation partners are Somali Ministry of Information and the National Union of Somali Journalists. Joint training activities will also be arranged with Somaliland Journalists Association (SOLJA).

title: Health and Education Sector Development through Skills and Knowledge Transfer in South Central Somalia
description:
The project aims at improving the capacity of public sector health and education institutions to provide quality services with special focus on vulnerable groups: women children and youth through skills and knowledge transfer by the Somali diaspora. The ov
erall objective of the project is to contribute to stabilization in South Central Somalia and Puntland through increasing access to basic services (health and education) and creating employment opportunities for the youth including women. In addition young
 Somalis will be placed in internship positions under the supervision of the diaspora experts at relevant institutions. The project trains health and education sector professionals to produce quality public services in health and education and to administe
r the resources of the sectors. The trainers are diaspora experts especially Finnish diaspora who work and share their expertise in the sectors.The Mid-Term Evaluation which was finalized in August 2018 showed that results have been gained in both health a
nd education sectors. For example the intake of patients at Yardimeli Hospital in Mogadishu has increased significantly in a short period of time from around 800 patients in July 2017 to around 4000 in March 2018. Moreover the number of assisted births inc
reased substantially. The diaspora experts placed at the Ministry of Education were successful in supporting the organizational reform and writing key strategic planning documents for the sector. According to the Mid-Term Evaluation the project was very re
levant in filling the gaps and specialized needs in the institutions. According to all participants both local and the diaspora the project was successful in producing sustainable results in skills and knowledge. The implementing partner is the Internation
al Organisation for Migration (IOM). From 2015 to 2019 Finland has supported the project with 4 420 000 EUR. From 2019 to 2021 the total budget for the second phase funded by Finland is 5 400 000 EUR. The budget is disbursed as follows: 1 MEUR in 2019; 24 
MEUR in 2020; 2 MEUR in 2021.

title: Small Charities Challenge Fund Projects Implemented in Somalia
description: This IATI activity file represents grant holders receiving funding from the Small Charities Challenge Fund (SCCF) for their projects in Somalia. The SCCF is the first fund from the Department for International Development (DFID) tailored to the needs of small, grassroots British charities doing outstanding development work. SCCF was launched within the existing UK Aid Direct Fund, which is DFID’s flagship challenge fund designed to support the UK’s commitments to achieving the Global Goals. SCCF is open to small UK-registered charities and not-for-profit organisations. Grants of up to £50,000 are available for projects of up to 2 years. The SCCF welcomes applications for projects strengthening the capacity of grassroots development organisations by working with the poor, vulnerable and most marginalised to carry out work in priority countries towards achieving the Global Goals.

title: Maternity Clinic and Training Project
description:
Long-running conflict has destroyed the infrastructure of the Somali state and the country has one of the worst health indicators in the world. The high-risk groups are 2.4 million children under age 5 and more than 3 million women of child-bearing age. Ac
cording to WHO the maternal mortality ratio is 732 per 100 000 live births although most of the maternal deaths would be preventable. Rebuilding the health sector is challenged by a shortage of professional staff financial resources and effective governanc
e and NGOs have played a key role in providing with these services. African Care?s Maternity Clinic and Training project has since its start in 2012 supported the development of the FinSom maternity clinic together with the local partner VMDSO. Results sho
w that the service of the clinic has decreased maternal mortality rate prevalence of tetanus raised awareness about exclusive breast feeding and FGM. The clinic is well-known in Afgoye and surrounding areas and a vital source of quality maternal health car
e for both expectant mothers and the community. Hence the maternal health care services are continued also in the continuation phase of the project.The project at hand seeks to further enhance the capacity and services of the partner and the clinic so that
 eventually maternal health services could be provided without development cooperation funding. This is done by investing in the education and training of the VMDSO staff and health workers and monitoring the long-term impact of the trainings. Simultaneous
ly invaluable information on the key challenges and development needs will be mapped out and used for future trainings.  Also the support of the sexual violence victims will be intensified. It will be expanded to an in-person counselling in addition to the
 telephone support. Open-access seminars and family counselling are likewise continued and further intensified. Seminars about gender equality family planning and gender-based violence work to dismantle unequal social structures through open dialogue. Proj
ect's beneficiaries are women in labour children victims of sexual violence clinic?s personnel and partner organization VMDSO.

title: Sahansaho ? Somalian aavikoitumista vastaan
description:
The key development problem which the project aims to find solutions to is the desertification leading to lack of livelihoods poverty and forced migration. The objective is sustainable use of natural resources and secured livelihood in the project areas. T
he project started in 2012 and it has been planned for 10 years. This continuation project will be its 4th and final phase.The outcomes of 2019-2022 will be:1. Environmental centers developed into regional hubs2. Educational institutions and trainers have 
expertise to provide environmental education3. Resilience of local communities to climate change and drought improved4. Implementation of policies related to natural resource management (NRM)The outputs will be: 1.1. Seedlings of locally successful species
 produced planted distributed and sold per year 1.2. Seed collection stands established and local availability of the seeds of the most important species secured 1.3. Operating models for the environmental centers developed 2.1. Trainers trained and traini
ng material produced 2.2. Training materials and research opportunities provided to universities and environmental education material provided to teachers 3.1. Charcoal and firewood consumption reduced in local communities 3.2. Agroforestry practices and s
oil and water conservation techniques adopted in local communities 4.1.  Network of the environmental actors built and environmental efforts and common initiatives coordinated at all project sites 4.2.  Policy reviews and briefs produced for policy dialogu
e with ministries of environment and implementation of environmental policies startedThe project is implemented at 3 sites in Somalia with the FSN's four partners in Finland and three partners in Somalia. The innovative cooperative model enforces the civil
 society in Somalia and creates new networks  that also promote peace and stability.The beneficiaries are local communities authorities and educational institutions among others.

title: Somaliland Health Sector Support (MIDA Finnsom IV)
description:
IOM MIDA Finnsom IV project focuses on contributing to improved health outcomes in Somaliland and particularly its remote regions. The additional funding supports the Somaliland Ministry of Health efforts to combat the COVID-19 pandemic health consequences
 for 3 months. To achieve this the project supports the capacity of public sector institutions to provide quality health services. Three outputs have been defined:1.) Local health professionals have skills/capacity to deliver quality health services2.) Loc
al health training institutions have improved competence and ability to train local health professionals 3.) Ministry of Health has increased capacity to steer manage and coordinate the health sector The Somali diaspora experts particularly the Finnish Som
ali diaspora experts are the actors in the capacity building efforts. They train the local health professionals and participate in developing strategies plans standards and curricula for health sector. Particular attention is given to women's and child hea
lth. In the long term the project is expected to contribute to better health outcomes for Somaliland population and especially the health outcomes for women and children.The first Finnish funded MIDA project was initiated already in 2008. The project has b
een evaluated twice and the findings suggest that the project has significantly strengthened public health institutions? ability to provide quality services in Somaliland. The findings and recommendations of evaluations have been duly notified in the plann
ing of the Finnsom IV phase: For example the project now focuses on the more remote regions in Somaliland where service provision is poorer than in the capital Hargeisa. Similarly following the recommendations the length of the assignments of diaspora expe
rts has been increased for Phase IV.To support the implementation of the project the National Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) also implements tailored trainings for the Ministry of Health.The duration of the Phase IV is four years from March 2017 un
til August 2020. The budget for the project is 4 300 000 Euros. Somalia is considered an LDC country.

title: F.a: Child Sensitive Social Protection in Somaliland
description:
The proposed project seeks to implement the child sensitive social protection activities targeting poor and vulnerable IDP households in Hargeisa and Borama. The main component of the project is regular cash transfers in the form of child grants with compl
ementary activities for enhancing sensitivity towards child nutrition, education and protection.

title: F.a: Children Protected in Families and Communities
description:
The proposed project aims to protect the most vulnerable and marginalised children, including children with disabilities, in Somaliland from multiple child protection risks and harms by building a child protection system which will be truly owned by the co
mmunities but will also have a strong link to relevant national laws and policies e.g. the Child Rights Act, the National Plan of Action for Children, the Child Protection Policy and the Alternative Care Policy, and the envisaged formal structures envisage
d by these normative frameworks.

title: FCA: Supporting national and local level reconciliation in Somalia
description:
Finn Church Aid (FCA) and the Network for Religious and Traditional Peacemakers have been active in mediation and local-level democratisation and institution building in Somalia for several years. In 2017 an expert was seconded to the Ministry for Interior
 Federal Affairs and Reconciliation (MoIFAR) at the request of the Somali government. The expert has held a key position in the team in charge of drafting the strategy for reconciliation. The Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland has supported the projec
t during the years 2018-2020. The first phase of the project saw the development of a nation-wide National Reconciliation Framework based on consultations with state and civil society actors. The second phase supported MoIFAR in the implementation of the n
ational reconciliation process while advancing the participation of women and youth in the process. The third phase of the project will ensure that the activities started in the second phase will continue without breaks. Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Fin
land will suppor the project with 204 233 Euros. The project will be implemented over a period of 5 months in 2020-2021.

title: Mustaqbaldoon
description:
The project contributes to the development problem of the vulnerability of the youth which is manifested in youth unemployment and limited access to income causing risky survival strategies such as informal quasi-legal or illegal activities and as a conseq
uence social problems like violence early sexual activity and a range of economic physical and psychological risks.The principal outcomes of the project are 1) Strengthened Civil Society and Local Administration 2) Increased motivation of youth to contribu
te to the society and 3) Increased economic empowerment of youth. The central activities include capacitating the local CSOs and public administration turning the risky survival strategies of youth to healthy ones and 3) training youth to recognize local i
ncome generation opportunities instead of leaving the country.  Developing countries? own economies have generated more jobs livelihood opportunities and well-being is the priority area of Finland's development policy the project is aimed at contributing t
o. Somalia is ranked as one of the bottom five countries in terms of gender inequality and therefore positive discrimination and affirmative measures will be taken to enhance the participation of young women and girls and to raise awareness about their par
ticular needs. The project aims to reduce inequality by emphasizing the rights of all youth as full and equal members of the communities where they live. Project respects climate sustainability too.The project capacitates CSOs and public administration to 
work with private sector according to multi-stakeholder approach. Helsinki Deaconess Institute?s Vamos services is acknowledged in a national level as a unique concept to support vulnerable youth's access to education and employment. The same concept will 
be used together with cooperation partners Y-PEER in Hargeisa and Gedo Development in Gedo. The principal beneficiaries of the project are the youth (15-35 years) who have dropped out from education and employment.

title: Human rights based approach to strengthening community mental health services in Somaliland
description:
The project tackles Somaliland's high burden of mental health problems coupled with a weak mental health care infrastructure which is not able to provide high-quality mental health services from a human rights perspective.The project aims to increase the a
ccess of people to community-based mental health services;promote the adoption of a human rights based approach to mental health in public/private mental health services;and to increase public awareness on mental health issues to decrease the stigma and di
scrimination against people with mental disorders in Somaliland.A special focus is on women/girls and vulnerable groups (SGBV survivorsIDPsdisabled personsprisoners).To support the sustainability of the intervention and to promote the long-term development
 of the mental health care infrastructure in Somalilandthe project will increase the capacity of health care officials to promote mental health from a human rights perspective to coordinate mental health services.The main cross-cutting themes of the projec
t are:health promotionhuman rightsgender equality and good governance.The main activities are: training community mental health workers and social workers to provide community mental health servicesprovision of out-patient treatmentsupporting the capacity 
of the MOH to plan and implement mental health services and policyand raising awareness on mental health.The main beneficiaries of the project are people in Somaliland suffering from mental disorderstheir families and communitiesvulnerable groups in need o
f mental health care civil society and health officials.PSR is well positioned to carry out the project with 30+ years of experience in health development projects also of mental health projects in post-conflict contexts.PSR has long-term project experienc
e in Somalia/Somaliland (2006-) and good local networks.The local partner GAVO is a well-respected local NGO with long-term experience in mental health projects.The Finnish partners FiPSR and Disability Partnership Finland have long-term experience that co
ntributes closely to the project.The project contributes to the FSA project in Jubaland and collaborates with the HDI project in Somaliland

title: Fighting TB in Somalia: public-private partnerships and inclusive communities
description:
The project is founded on PSR's previous projects in Somalia which have developed new strategies to tackle tuberculosis (TB) ? especially in community and private sector engagement. A special focus will be placed on women and vulnerable community members: 
disabled persons IDPs and prisoners. Tuberculosis is a central health problem in Somalia. The increase of multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is a global threat ? fighting against MDR-TB in Somalia benefits all countries. Another central problem is 
the low treatment coverage rate of about 37% leaving far too many cases untreated further transmitting tuberculosis to others. The impact targets of the project are to: a) tackle multi-drug resistant tuberculosis; and b) increase the tuberculosis case dete
ction rate. The long-term objective of the project is to contribute to the reduction of the tuberculosis burden in Somalia with the following means:1. Increase the access of women and vulnerable groups to TB services (such as disabled personsIDPs and priso
ners)2. Increase TB referrals from the private sector3. Improve the quality of TB treatment in both the public and private sector4. Improve the quality of TB laboratory work.The central partners of the project are the National Tuberculosis Programmes of So
maliland and Somalia. PSR has a central role in developing the national tuberculosis diagnostic infrastructure in Somalia. The project will support the National TB Reference Laboratories in Somaliland and South-Central Somalia as well as will treatment of 
tuberculosis patients in 3 clinics in Hargeisa and Mogadishu. These clinics will develop innovative community public and private sector engagement models to increase case detection improve treatment quality and to increase public awareness and decrease sti
gma/discrimination. The clinics will also provide HIV services and nutritional support for malnourished patients (with WFP).Together with the local administration the tuberculosis clinics will be transformed into health centers providing specialized tuberc
ulosis services by the end of 2022 to support integration with basic health services and sustainability after the project has ended.

title: F.a: Health + Business manual
description:
ISF is developing a Health and Business Manual to provide participatory framework for integrating livelihood support and FGM prevention activities within same communities. The manual will be a tool for project officers and volunteer facilitators to raise a
wareness on FGM and to teach basic skills for starting up or improving micro-business among uneducated, often illiterate community members.

title: Mobiili Terveyskaliniikka - Daryeel hanke Somaliassa Afmadowssa
description:
The Daryeel Mobile Health Clinic ?project aims at providing preventive and basic health care services to rural areas outside of Afmadow town in Jubaland Somalia. The project is executed by the Finland-Somalia Association (FSA) with partner NGO SAHDA and th
e Jubaland Ministry of Health. The project is a continuation of the Maternal and Child Health Services Clinic ?project that the FSA has ran since 2011 in Afmadow town. Based on an agreement with the Jubaland Ministry of Health the FSA has been asked to swi
tch its foces to more remote villages through a mobile clinic. The mobile clinic is to start its operations in 2018 depending on permission from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Finland. With this application the project plan is to continue the Mobile He
alth Clinic through 2019-2020 a total of three years.The main development problem that the project aims to solve is the poor access to preventive and basic health care in the Afmadow area in Jubaland Somalia. The project aims to take health services close 
to remote communities where it is difficult to get access to basic healthcare and where travelling is a challenge. By curing and providing basic health services in remote locations the project contrib-utes to creating a healthier community and society with
 people who are able to work for their own livelihoods. In this context the project contributes significantly to achieving the UN?s Sustainable Development Goals. The development impact that the project strives for is to increase the wellbeing of the commu
nities in the project area and to decrease the number of diseases and illnesses.The mobile clinic concept includes three core outputs:1. Supporting existing healthcare by providing health services in suburbs nearby villages and towns2. Providing supportive
 services in first aid family reproductive services and interventions reducing infectious diseases in the target villages3. Reducing travelling for health services from the towns as well as building the competence of the local community in health particula
rly by giving tools and knowledge to local midwives.

title: IOM Enhancing the Institutional Capacity of the Immigration and Naturalization Directorate of Somalia
description:
Somalia is recovering from decades of war and collapse of state structures. The core state functions are now recovering but the legitimacy and capacity of the state are still weak. Conflicts and violence remain a significant challenge. The prolonged confli
ct has resulted in porous air sea and land-border management providing a thriving conduit for Transnational organized immigration crimes. In order to improve security and strengthen state legitimacy the Federal Government of Somalia is aiming at strengthen
ing the capacity of the Immigration and Naturalisation Directorate IND in line with the National Development Plan. The project will focus on developing the institutional capacity of IND especially its HR Department in order to strengthen the legitimacy of 
the Federal Government of Somalia in the field of immigration and border management. The project will utilize diaspora and international experts in developing capacity and strengthen IND?s infrastructural capabilities to deliver quality public services.   
The project will be implemented by the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) during a period of 14 months in 2020 - 2021. Finland supports the project with 1 000 000 euros.

description: Long term partnership with a local company / organisation (e.g. joint venture; subcontractor, import or other contract agreement )

title: F.a: Improving employment and livelihood opportunities for Somali and   youth through TVET and business skills development
description:
1. Project: 12091 Improving employment and livelihood opportunities for Somali and   youth through TVET and business skills development    2. Project area and Country: Hargeisa, Somaliland3. Project justification: Somaliland is one of the poorest nations i
n the world. About 60% of Somalilanders are youth aged 15-35 years old; among those 40% are aged 15-29. The overall adult literacy rate across Somaliland is of 45.3% (50.2% among men and 40.2 among women). The unemployment rate in Somaliland among youth ag
ed 14-29 is 67%, one of the highest rate in the world, with women experiencing higher unemployment rate at 74% than men at 61%. The majority of the employment is classified as vulnerable employment with low wages, low level of social security, poor working
 conditions, and limited worker rights, with women experiencing more vulnerability than men do. Poor to no level of education leaves the vast majority of youth with little opportunity to access the labour market, rendering them without hope and perspective
. 4. The main objective and the expected results:The project aims to contribute to sustainable and profitable employment and self-employment opportunities for male and female youth from IDPs, host communities and returnees in Hargeisa of Somaliland. The ai
m is going to be achieved by following FCA?s thematic pillars of right to livelihood (R2L) and right to quality education (R2QE). FCA intends to pilot the integrated approach of Linking Learning to Earning (LL2E) aimed at providing both male and female you
th with quality and market driven TVET trainings, which are informed by labor market assessment, combined with 1) career guidance and counselling, 2) close collaboration with private sector for market driven curriculum development, and provision of interns
hip, apprenticeship and job placement, 3) entrepreneurship and business development, and 4) effective collaboration with the government institutions and private sector to promote TVET, employability and business opportunities.  Right-holders/beneficiaries:
 60 TVET learners and 410 male and female secondary school learners. 5. Duty bearers: Local government agencies, parents, caregivers, community leaders and traditional and religious elders, and private sector. 6. Implementing partner: FCA Somalia Country P
rogramme

title: International Committee of the Red Cross ICRC/ Finnish Red Cross FRC humanitarian operations 2020
description: Humanitarian operation in Somalia

title: Teaching the Teachers
description: This project addresses the need for locally trained female teachers and teaching assistants in Galgaduud region of Somalia, which until seven years ago had no tradition of education. This organisation has already opened eight schools and runs four literacy campaigns, but the difficulties of recruiting and retaining teachers are immense. There are very few trained teachers from the area, and teachers brought in from elsewhere tend to stay for only short periods, and are exclusively male. There is a severe shortage of trained teachers in Somalia, and very few women have had the opportunity to train up to a professional standard. This particular project provides teacher training through a two year certificate course run by a local university but based in schools. This means female student teachers can live at home, making accessing the training easier. Because they are drawn from the local area, they are less likely to leave the region. The impact will be long term and educationally significant.

title: Inter-agency collective service for COVID-19 Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE) interventions
description:
Through a common service platform, implementing partners will jointly administer activities geared at curtailing COVID-19 transmission and fostering community resilience in dealing with the shock of the epidemic.

The combined forces of CCCM and WASH aim to deliver essential COVID-19 risk communication and community engagement activities while establishing necessary water points and handwashing platforms for better hygiene practices.  Moreover, the use of radio media will look to provide an additional layer of awareness and critical thinking related to community-based responses and prevention of COVID-19 transmission.
